SummaryOfEvents: ON THE 1ST OF FEBRUARY 2006 AT 19:40 HRSM/V ALICAN DEVAL WAS PASSING CAPO PASSERO'S LIGHTHOUSE WITH COURSE NE TOWARDS INSTANBUL WHEN THE VESSEL CHANGED HER COURSE TO FIND RECOVERY AT POZZALLO HARBOUR DUE TO ADVERSE WEATHER CONDITIONS. AT 20:30 HRS THE SHIP WAS VERY CLOSE TO THE COAST, SO THE MASTER REALIZED THE DANGER AND GAVE ORDER TO PUT THE STEARING ALL AT LEFT POSITION WITH FULL AHEAD ENGINE. AT 20:33 HRS THE SHIP'S DEFINITIVELY GROUNDED. THE MASTER OF THE SHIP GAVE ORDER TO PUT THE ENGINE FULL ASTERN TRYING TO REFLOAT THE SHIP. AFTER SEVERAL ATTEMPTS THE MASTER ORDERED THE STOP OF THE MAIN ENGINE AND TRANSMITTED THE SITUATION TO THE OWNER'S OFFICE AND TO THE COASTGUARD LOCAL OFFICE OF AUGUSTA.

The fishing vessel MARY-LIS was fishing in Femer Belt on the evening of 1 February 2006, with a crew of three onboard. At around 19.00  hours LT, as the last part of the catch was being tackled in, the ship suddenly heeled to starboard.
The skipper, who was handling the tackle winch from the deck, immediately eased out the winch. The ship did not get back on an even keel, but found balance for a brief moment with the rail under water.
The skipper engaged the propeller and swung the ship around in an attempt to get the sea from aft in order to minimize the list. This was done without any positive result and the ship capsized. 
The skipper managed to get out of the wheelhouse.
The two others crewmembers, who were on the deck amidships, got caught under the shelter deck but they managed to get out.
Together they managed to disengage the life raft from its stowing position on the top of the wheelhouse and to release it. The ship’s second man drifted away while they were working with the life-raft and the others lost contact with him in the dark. 
The water was very cold, and none of the crewmembers had had the time to put on life jackets or immersion suits.
The skipper and the 3rd man entered the life raft and managed to release it from the ship.
The Danish Admiral Fleet was alarmed by the ship’s EPIRB and a search and rescue operation was initiated.

The Danish Admiral Fleet tried to establish contact with the ship via Lyngby Ra-dio. As the ship did not reply to the calls, ships and a rescue helicopter began searching for the ship.

The skipper and the ship’s 3rd man were rescued from the raft by the helicopter approximately 1½ hours after the ship’s EPIRB had been activated.

Shortly after, the ship’s 2nd man was found dead.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

At about 1955 on 19 January 2006, the fishing vessel GREENHILL grounded on the shore between Ardglass and Ringfad Point on the east coast of Northern Ireland.  The vessel was returning to Ardglass with her skipper and two deckhands on board.  After the grounding, the vessel was manoeuvred into open water and started to flood rapidly.  At 2002 she foundered in a depth of 24m.  The skipper and two deckhands initially clung on to the vessel's liferaft canister.  The skipper then managed to inflate the liferaft, but it inflated upside down; by the time the skipper managed to right it, the deckhands had disappeared.  The skipper was rescued from the liferaft by the Portaferry lifeboat, which had been tasked by the MCA to locate fv GREENHILL after receiving a distress signal from the vessel's EPIRB.  The body of one of the deckhands was later recovered from the seabed close to the wreck of fv GREENHILL.  The body of the second deckhand was not found.
Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Loss of life

While M/V MARIBELLA was navigating upwards the Mississippi River, proceeding to mile 179, in order to discharge her cargo, in full loaded condition, having pilot onboard, ran aground at a mud bank (42ft) in mile 156,2 (College Point). Vessel's draft was 47 ft. When the vessel approached one (1) mile from College Point, where the river makes a U-turn, a tug boat pushing seven barges (approximate length 350 metres) was observed visually and on radar screen. The direction of the tow was at approximately 45° angle to the riverside, thus resulting to the restriction of navigable waters (depth over 50 ft). The pilot and the Master attempted several times to speak with the tug master calling him in the appropriate frequency in VHF and using the vessel's whistle, with negative results. In order to avoid collision with the tow and as there was not any better alnernative, due to restricted waters (1,5 cable), limited time and constraint in vessel's manoeuvrability the pilot advised the Master to  start making a sharper strbd turn which resulted in the vessel's pulling out of the bend earlier than the normal. M/V "MARIBELLA"    touched bottom and ran aground in position 
29°  58.95N - 090°  49.359W , at 06:12 hrs LT. 
All proper notifications were carried out immediately after the incident as per instructions included in vessel's SOPEP. All adjacent traffic was notified accordingly by the Pilot. The checklist from SOPEP, regarding GROUNDING was activated and all tanks  were sounded  in order to determine that there were no leaks. The Master in consultation with the Pilot tried to manouver the vessel ahead and astern, hard over the sides, using Main Engine and Rudder, which were confirmed clear in an effort to break free, but in vain.
At 07:20 hrs LT the first two (2) tugs arrived in the scene with two (2) more arrived on or about 09:00 hrs LT. One (1) hour later with the assistance of the tugs the vessel was run afloat.
After a close-up examination carried out by Class, relevant report was issued mentioning that the vessel is fit to retain her  Class.

On the 15 January 2006 the MV CONQUEROR, loaded with a cargo of 15,525 mt of corn in bulk, arrived at the port of San Lorenzo, Argentina and was directed to berth at the San Benito Berth.

At 03.00 hours LT the vessel was in position at the berth and berthing manoeuvres were almost completed, with two head ropes and two springs forward and two stern ropes and two springs aft.  The attending port pilot received instructions from the terminal to shift the vessel approximately 8 metres astern due to operational reasons.

To carry out this movement at the aft station, one stern line and one spring were paid out from the vessel’s side and the corresponding two others were kept on the winch drums.The second mate, who was in charge of organising and monitoring the mooring operations at the aft station, was at the time standing on the port side open roller chock.  As soon as the spring was released from the vessel’s side, he tried to stop it with his left foot, while his right foot remained on the fore roller.

The spring was by then paying out with a high velocity due to the vessel’s movement.  When the second mate put his foot on the rope to stop it, his foot was swept away by the rope’s speedy movement in the direction of the second spring, which was running through the mooring fore roller entrapping his foot between the two springs.

The second mate tried desperately to pull his foot clear by using his right leg.  In doing so, both legs were entrapped between the spring ropes and the rollers.  The mooring roller chocks have a steel pipe welded around the chock assembly to prevent the ropes from slipping out of the chocks.  The second mate’s feet were caught between the rope/chock/pipe combination and he suffered serious injuries to one of his feet, resulting in the instant loss of one foot and serious injuries to the other.

The master who was on the bridge wing, heard the shouting from the poop deck and tried to stop the vessel from going astern by ordering slow ahead on the main engine, but by this time the second mate was already seriously injured. The able seaman, who was operating the winch, released the tension on the spring by paying out the winch drum and the second officer was released from the ropes.  The crewmembers started to administer first aid.  An ambulance was called and at 04.00 hours LT the second mate was taken to the Rosario City hospital.

On 19 January 2006 the second mate succumbed to his injuries at the hospital and died.

The fishing vessel, stern trawler, TANNISBUGT was fishing for lobster with quadrupled trawls on the White Bank.

The shooting of the trawls was done manually. From the trawl lane on the aft deck the trawls were eased out via the stern slope. During such an operation one crewmember stepped onto the trawl lane. He was caught by a loop on one trawl and pulled over-board via the slope.

The crewmember became paralysed because of the cold water, and he could not be rescued by the use of the ship’s life saving appliances. 

Another crewmember jumped into the sea to rescue his shipmate, but he was also instantly paralysed because of the cold water, and had to be taken on board again by the skipper and the engineer.

A search and rescue operation was launched and another fishing vessel found the crewmember drowned 500 metres east of the position of the accident.
Consequences1: Ship remains fit to proceed,Loss of life

SOLASStatus: FARLEY MOWAT: Unknown/unspecified, ORIENTAL BLUEBIRD: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: On 9th January 2006 the M/V Oriental Bluebird was drifting and waiting  for Company Instructions. At about 06.20 hours LT a message was received from the Duty Officer that an unidentified vessel was approaching Oriental Bluebird;  this was the  M/V Farley Mowat, which was approaching at the distance about 2 or 3 cables. Instantly the engine was ordered to standby and a continous, short blast was sounded as a warning, but the M/V Farley Mowat continued to approach and it seemed that there would be a collision. The Oriental Bluebird's engine was started and the vessel increased its speed up to the maximum to shrug off the M/V Farley Mowat. At 16.20 hours  LT the Oriental Bluebird stopped and resumed drifting until further instruction. The crew investigated and found that there was a shallow scratch of about 4 meters long on her starboard side shell; no other damage was found.

SUSANN departed Castellon on 4th January 2006. Destination was Sfax, Tunisia where all the cargo (48 container units) was to be discharged.
The weather conditions were fair to moderate until 7th January when south-east winds increased and reached force 7Bs.  During the night of 7th to 8th January, the weather deteriorated gradually after midnight.
At 11h35 on 8th January, the Master tried to send a message to the local agent in Sfax to inform him about the delay in ETA owing to rough weather when the vessel was hit by a wave.  When the Master looked outside, he noticed that the main deck was completely under water.  The vessel started listing.  At 11h40 SUSANN experienced a black out.  The ship's generator failed and the emergency generator also failed to start automatically.  Manual starting of main generator was impossible due to the huge starboard list (nearly 50 degrees to starboard).
Distress messages were sent by the Master when it became apparent that SUSANN should be abandonned.  Assistance was requested and all crew boarded the liferafts and were later picked up by a rescue helicopter and a navy ship.

The MV DANIAL arrived at the New Mangalore port at 01.48 hours LT, on 30 December 2005 to discharge a cargo of 33,040 mt of Urea in bulk, loaded in Port Sur, Oman. At 05.30 hours LT on 30 December 2005, the vessel berthed at the No.3 berth. At 07.30 hours LT the discharging operation commenced, using the vessel’s cranes and shore cranes with grabs. On 07 January 2006 the discharging operation was nearing completion.  As is normal practice at this port, when the cargo discharging was nearing the end, bulldozers were lowered in the holds to help gather and unload the remaining cargo in the holds. Stevedores were also working in the holds to sweep/clear the remaining cargo from the sides of the holds, hoppers and corrugated bulkheads.At 06.20 hours LT on 07 January 2006, one of the stevedores was dislodging some of the urea cargo from the sides of the hold by stepping on it and causing it to slide down to the bottom of the hold.  At one time, he slipped and fell down to the bottom of the hold causing a heap of urea cargo to fall down on top of him.  The stevedore was totally buried under the cargo.The bulldozer operator who saw this happen raised the alarm and cargo operations were suspended.  The crewmembers and the stevedores started to extract the stevedore from under the cargo. About 15 minutes later the stevedores managed to recover their colleague and the crewmembers tried to resuscitate him.He was later put on a stretcher and lifted from the hold by means of the crane and taken to the port hospital where he was pronounced dead.

Location: FERRY WAYS UK RO-RO TERMINAL IPSWICH UK
SummaryOfEvents:
On 7th July 2006 the vessel arrived at Ipswich port berth ro-ro two at midnight, and seamen o/s Dinca and o/s Staicu  began unlashing trailers on weather deck.
Three trailers were left on aft part. The tug master, operated by an ABP stevedore driver, connected and picked up a trailer on the starboard side. Seaman O/s Dinca took out the trestle from under the middle of the trailer and waited for it to be discharged. When nothing happened he moved to the aft and found seaman o/s Staicu trapped between the trailer and the accommodation bulkhead. He shouted to the driver to move the trailer ahead. Once this was done he and the bosun put o/s Staicu in a safe place, and called for help.
The ambulance arrived after about 10 minutes, and within the next 30 minutes o/s Staicu had been taken to hospital. In the statement taken by the Master in hospital on 08th July 2006 at 18.45 hours LT, o/s Staicu said: when theTug master connected and lifted up the trailer, o/s Staicu went to the aft to unlash two lashing chains. The starboard chain disconnected and there was not enough slack left, so he asked the driver to push the trailer back a little. Once this had been done o/s Staicu went again to unlash the second chain, and it was then that the trailer moved back and trapped him between the bulkhead of accommodation and trailer.

SOLASStatus: CAPE BRADLEY: Unknown/unspecified, STAR HERDLA: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
The chemical tanker Cape Bradley is in the North-East Lane of the Dover Strait TSS, course made good 043°, speed 14 knots close to "South-East Ridens" buoy. 
The general cargo Star Herdla is in the South-West Lane of the Dover Strait Tss, course made good 108°, speed 11.3 knots heading to Boulogne-sur-Mer approaches.
The visibility varies from five to one cable.
The Cape Bradley after "South-East Ridens" buoy alters course made good to 020°, in line with the lane. The OOW, supported by an AB as helmsperson, sees on the radar display several ship contacts, both on port and starboard sides, transiting in the same direction and one contact on the port side heading 108°, thus "crossing". 
At the same time, Star Herdla is close to begin to cross the North-East Lane. The master, supported by the Chief Officer, the OOW and an AB as helmsperson, observes on the radar display five contacts heading in the North-East Lane on his right hand side at various ranges. He alters course to the right in order to pass on the aft of the two first. At 07:15 hours, the three other ships are all about on the same parallel at the range of about 1.6 mile. Star Herdla can cross on the bow of Cape Bradley, which is among these ships with a CPQ of 0.21 mile. Anyway the Master keeps on turning right to course 160°, likely to pass on Cape Bradley port side and then to cross on her aft. At an estimated range of 0.6 or 0.7 mile from her the master suddenly decides a hard to port manoeuvre at a speed of 10 knots. 
Both ships, Cape Bradley maintaining her speed and shyly altering her course to port side, and Star Herdla during a hard to port manoeuvre collided in the French territorial waters between 07:19 and 07:20 hours at position 50°45.447 N and 001°22.8543 E, that is in the bearing 296° from Cape Alprech at 7.9 miles.
The collision angle between the two ships is about 90°. On Star Herdla the impact is on the aft of the starboard side at the gangway level. On Cape Bradley the impact is at the bow
For Star Herdla the immediate consequence is a blackout leading to the loss of the main engine. Star Herdla is adrift in the North-East Lane without any manoeuvring capacity. Cape Bradley, after the collision keeps her course in the North-East Lane with a slower speed.

Location: In the Estuary of the Loire
SummaryOfEvents:
Le 04 Janvier 2006, à 20:22  heures locales, les deux navires citernes transporteurs de gaz de pétrole liquéfié (GPL) « Sigmagas » battant pavillon Antigua et Barbuda de la compagnie Sloman Neptun Schiffarts et « Happy Bride » battant pavillon Île de Man de la compagnie  Hanseatic shipping Co Ltd se sont abordés dans le chenal de Donges par le travers du poste 5.

Aucun blessé n’a été à déplorer. Aucun incendie ne s’est déclaré, il n’y a eu ni explosion, ni prise de gîte  anormale.
Toutefois il est apparu très vite que du fioul lourd s’échappait du bordé du Happy Bride  près du point d’impact par une brèche  au niveau de la soute à combustible n°1 qui contenait environ 60 tonnes de fioul lourd pour la propulsion.
La capitainerie a autorisé le navire à accoster au plus vite au poste 3  pour tenter de circonscrire  la pollution.

Dès 23 :18 heures, le fioul lourd de la soute endommagée a été pompé dans des camions citernes.

De son côté, le « Sigmagas » avec l’aide du remorqueur  Croisic a accosté à l’Arceau vers 21:24 heures.

Environ 30 tonnes de fioul lourd se sont échappées dans l’estuaire de la Loire engendrant une pollution éparse le long de  la rivière.
L’Alcyon, bâtiment de la Marine Nationale spécialisé dans la lutte antipollution a été dépêché sur place.

SOLASStatus: KLEIN FAMILIE: Unknown/unspecified, SICHEM PANDORA: Unknown/unspecified
Location: In the Northeastbound Lane of the off Casquets TSS
SummaryOfEvents:
On 5 January 2006 the Klein Familie, a wooden longliner a little less than 15 metres in length sailed from Cherbourg around 04:5 hours in the morning, with six crew  on board. She set courses of the north northwest. The weather was good with an easterly wind. 
At 08:48 hours the merchant ship Alblas reported sighting a red rocket flare; at 09:45 hours she picked up a survivor from a liferaft who stated that he was a crew member of the Klein Familie.

No trace was found of any of the other crew

A large number of airborne and nautical resources were deployed during 05 January in an effort to locate other survivors and toestablish which ships were likely to have been in the area when the accident occurred.

The wreck of the Klein Familie was pinpointed and identified on 06 January by a French Navy minesweeper and a team of divers was sent down to ascertain  whether any bodies remained on board  and to make a  description of the wreck  for the technical investigators of the Beamer and  the legal authorities.
On the basis of the radar recordings made by Jobourg Traffic and observations made in situ, the chemical carrier Sichem Pandora was diverted to Dunkirk in the evening of 5 January 2006 following a Court decision. She was allowed to leave on 27 January 2006.

Desh Rakshak arrived off Port Phillip on the morning of 4 January 2006, with about 80 000 tonnes of crude oil cargo on board, and at 0800 a pilot boarded the ship for the transit from sea to the Melbourne outer anchorage. 

The pilot planned to enter the port to the west of the track marked by the main leading lights, to keep the ship out of an opposing tidal flow for as long as possible. When the ship was almost abeam of Point Lonsdale Lighthouse, the pilot thought he could see the high and low main leading lights just open to the west. This indicated to him that the ship was on the edge of the Great Ship Channel. However, the ship was further to the west than the pilot thought. 

The ship continued the transit and anchored at 1154. No one on board the ship observed anything that might have suggested that the ship had grounded during the pilotage. 

At about 1245, the chief mate found the level in the lower fore peak water ballast tank rising. He told the master, and they decided to pump out the tank and inspect it. The inspection revealed that the tank’s shell plating had been holed. 

The ship berthed in Geelong on 5 January and temporary repairs were carried out before it sailed for Singapore on 19 January, where it was dry-docked for permanent repairs.

The investigation found that the ship probably grounded at about 0825, when it was almost abeam of Point Lonsdale, while transiting from sea to the Melbourne outer anchorage.

SummaryOfEvents:
On 18 December 2005, the MV GEORGE arrived at the port of Ghent, Belgium and berthed at the Sidmar Berth to discharge a cargo of iron ore in bulk.

The discharging operation was completed on 21 December 2005 at 23.05 hours LT and the crew members started to clean the no.5 cargo hold from cargo residues.  The master made the necessary preparations for the vessel’s sailing at 01.00 hours LT.

At 00.40 hours on 22 December 2005, a pilot and two channel helmsman boarded the vessel in preparation for the vessel’s departure.  In the meantime, the crew members were working in the no.5 cargo hold sweeping the last residues of iron ore and filling plastic buckets.  The buckets were being lifted from the cargo hold by means of a portable air operated winch, which was situated on deck on the vessel’s centreline.  The bosun was operating the winch while another seaman was carrying the buckets on the main deck to the port side of the vessel.  When the work was almost finished, the bosuns left the area to go and close the No. 3 cargo hold hatches and left the operation of the winch to the seaman.

The two seamen, who were working in the cargo hold, filled the last bucket and one of them climbed out of the hold and went near the winch on deck and took over the winching operation, while the crew member on deck carried the buckets to the port side.The other seaman, who was in the hold, hooked the last bucket onto the winch hook and as the winch operator started to haul up the bucket, he walked away with the intention to climb out of the hold.

Some time later he heard an unusual noise and as he turned round he saw a person falling down into the hold.  The winch mechanism was at an unusual angle and the bucket, which was being winched, stopped half way up the hold.The alarm was raised and assistance was requested from the port authorities.

At 01.00 hours LT an ambulance and a doctor arrived on board and the seaman who had fallen into the hold was declared dead.

SummaryOfEvents: A 5000grt reefer was navigating a narrow channel in the approaches to a port. The staff captain and the chief officer were on the bridge wings with searchlights. A 1:50000 scale chart was in use, which was the best scale BA chart available for the area. The port entry was not planned in detail because of the limitations of the chart in use, but the master, who was taken specifically for his navigational expertise in the region of operation had previously entered the port on a number of occasions  At 1758, speed was about 3 knots when the master started to manoeuvre the ship from a course of 300 to an intended course of 000. At 1800, the ship hit a rock on her port side, which penetrated No 8 water ballast tank on the port side. The vessel arrived alongside at 1820. The ship manager's investigation report concluded that there was no evidence of equipment failure, and that the grounding  was due to the vessel turning either later or more slowly than planned, and identified the absence of a suitable large scale chart, and darkness as being contributory factors. The report recommended that an experienced local pilot be ordered when operating in ports for which large scale charts and other maritime publications are not available, and to only enter such ports during daylight.

Location: Baia da Praia do Norte, Faial, Azores
SummaryOfEvents:
The 15,145gt Bermuda registered container vessel CP VALOUR, grounded in a bay off the NW coast of the island of Faial, Azores, on 9 December 2005.  The next day, in worsening weather conditions. the vessel's hull began to fracture, eventually causing substantial pollution to the coast of Faial, and to the islands of Pico and Sao Jorge.  The subsequent salvage operation was unsuccessful and she was declared a constructive total loss about 3 weeks later.
The vessel had been on a liner voyage from Montreal, Canada, to Valencia, Spain, when one of her main engine cylinder units was found to be overheating due to a cooling water leak.  The vessel continued on her planned track towards the central Azores at slow speed, while the Master and chief engineer decided on the best course of action.  They decided to head for a bay, which they assessed would be sheltered from a heavy SW'ly swell, in order to make the necessary repairs.  A cylinder head needed to be lifted and calm waters was essential.  The Master discussed the proposed action with the managers who then further discussed the proposal with the owners.  Agreement was reached and the Master was granted permission to proceed.
The bay contained a charted designated anchorage, but the largest scale British Admiralty chart of the island was of 1:175,000 scale.  Such a chart is not normally considered suitable for close inshore navigation.  There was only a single sounding of 36 metres in the bay.
The passage planning of the vessel's approach into the bay was rudimentary.  The bridge and anchoring team had different views on how to approach and anchoring operation was to be carried out.  In the event, the Master did not use the bridge team to its full capability, took on too much himself and became overloaded.
The vessel grounded at a speed of 6 knots while the Master was manoeuvring the vessel in the bay in search of calm water.  The engine telegraph had been inadvertently left on half ahead for several minutes.
Following the grounding, the intial salvage attempts by a local tug were unsuccessful.  The vessel was driven further aground the next day as the wind veered to blow directly into the bay.  The 1172 MT of heavy fuel and 118 MT of gas oil onboard began leaking into the sea.
A powerful salvage tug was on scene about 24 hours after the initial grounding but her attempts to re-float the vessel were also unsuccessful.
CP VALOUR was abandoned on 25 December 2005, after all the IMO classified hazardous cargo had been safely removed, along with 450 cubic metres of oil and water from her bunker tanks. Operations to remove the vessel from the beach began in the summer of 2006.

Location: Westbound fairway of Elbe River, south of Brunsbüttel Locks
SummaryOfEvents:
After being involved in a collision with the container feeder vessel ARCTIC OCEAN earlier that evening (please see other record entry ref. C0006669), the capsized wreck of the general cargo vessel MARITIME LADY drifted in a strong ebb stream until it came to rest about 30 minutes after the collision in a position in the westbound fairway, 0.75 miles south-west of the exit basin of Brunsbuttel Locks.
After the collision, Brunsbüttel Locks were closed until 2100.  The first vessel to then leave the locks was the Bahamian registered chemical tanker SUNNY BLOSSOM.  She had a pilot on board and was to head west, to the North Sea, after leaving the lock's exit basin.
After leaving the lock basin, SUNNY BLOSSOM was attempting to make the turn to the west, when her stern struck the wreck of MARITIME LADY, causing serious propeller damage and a total loss of propulsion.  She then continued south accross the Elbe River, until she grounded on the south bank.  There was only slight damage to her hull and no pollution was caused.  At 0030 on 6 December, SUNNY BLOSSOM was refloated by tugs and towed to Elbe Harbour, Brunsbüttel, arriving at 0145.

SummaryOfEvents:

At the same time, the Gibraltar registered general cargo vessel MARITIME LADY was in the westbound fairway approaching the exit from the lock basin and heading for the North Sea.
The two vessels collided at 1957, with the result that MARITIME LADY capsized.  All her crew were evacuated safely.  ARCTIC OCEAN suffered minimal damage.
The capsized wreck of MARITIME LADY drifted in a strong ebb stream until it came to rest about 30 minutes after the collision in a position in the westbound fairway, 0.75 miles south-west of the exit basin of Brunsbuttel Locks.

Location: Approach channel to the port of Newhaven
SummaryOfEvents:
At 0652 on 5 December 2005, the French registered ro-ro passenger ferry DIEPPE ran aground in the approach channel to the port of Newhaven on the south coast of England.  The grounding position was 15 metres east of the channel centreline where, according to the latest edition of the locally produced chart, the Master should have been able to expect sufficient depth of water to safely navigate DIEPPE through the approach channel.  The vessel refloated 60 minutes later at 0752, with assistance provided from the local tug and the onset of the flood tide.  
There were no injuries or pollution, and the vessel did not sustain damage.
The accident occurred less than 3 months after the MAIB published its report on the SARDINIA VERA grounding at Newhaven in January 2005.  The report made recommendations to NPP, Transmanche Ferries, the MCA and the DfT to ensure that similar incidents were avoided.  As a consequence, this report has taken the opportunity to examine the progress made by the various recipients towards fulfilling complete implementation of their individual recommendations.

The vessel anchored at Milford Haven at about 2300 on 26 Nov 05 in preparation to embark a mix of 4 oil products.	The master and chief officer decided to conduct a freefall launch on 27 Nov.

The Chief Officer was in charge of the drill but there was no explanation of what the drill would comprise and no brief was given. Prior to the drill being conducted it was custom and practice to test the A frame arrangements to ensure that the lifeboat could be recovered.  During the test a hydraulic leak was discovered.  As it was now impossible to recover the lifeboat it was decided to conduct a simulated freefall drill.  The chief officer had assembled the Cadet, and 3 ABs and 2nd officer for the drill.  The lifeboat was supported by the chain falls.	One of the ABs was instructed by the Chief Officer to sit in the second coxswain's position and operate the manual release system.  There was no other instruction given by the Chief Officer.  The by pass valve, which was in the closed position, was not opened despite the clear instruction that it should be in the open position for manual release of the system.    

The hook released after the AB fully operated hand wheel.  The Chief Officer then instructed the AB to turn the hand wheel back to the set position.  In the meantime the AB/cook tried to reset the release hook using the resetting handle.  He could not do so.  The Chief Officer somewhat irate removed the AB from the lifeboat and leaned into the lifeboat and fully unwound the hand wheel.  The release hook was then reset but because of the retained hydraulic pressure it was only partially reset.  When the vessel was berthing the release hook slipped from the release pawl and the lifeboat launched.

There was confusion whether the Chief Officer opened the by pass valve - the AB said that he was the only person in the boat, the cadet said that the Chief Officer remained outside the boat and did not open the by pass valve.  Other issues - poor signage & drill conduct.

The MV TEEN arrived at New Mangalore Port on 22nd November 2005 and made fast at No. 3 berth at 00.54 hours LT on 23rd November 2005.

At 07.00 hours LT, loading of iron ore fines commenced using the vessel’s cranes and steel net slings lined with tarpaulin.  The cargo was brought by tipper lorries and dumped onto the slings.

Between 16.00 hours and 16.54 hours loading operations were suspended as the vessel was requested to shift to the No. 2 berth, following which, the loading operations were resumed.

At this stage, the master of the vessel issued a Note of Protest to the stevedores, alleging that the weight of the cargo in the slings was exceeding the safe working load of the vessel’s cranes, of 25 mt.  At 02.00 hours on 24 November 2005, as the No. 4 crane lifted a sling to about 4 ½ metres from the berth, the crane runner came to an abrupt stop.  The crane driver apparently decided to lower the sling back onto the berth.  Suddenly the crane jib, main housing and the operator’s cabin fell down to the main deck of the vessel, with the boom’s end coming to rest on the berth.

The crane operator fell out of the crane’s cabin onto the vessel’s main deck between the No. 4 hatch and the No. 4 mast house. Other stevedores immediately rushed the injured stevedore to the port hospital, but he died later as a result of his injuries.

The ro-ro passenger ship Finnsailor, en route from Travemünde, Germany, to Malmö, Sweden, was approaching the traffic separation scheme rounding the Gedser Reef.  In good time before entering the separation scheme the Officer of Watch (OOW) on the bridge of the Finnsailor observed, visually and on the radar, three ships on a parallel course heading east in the separation scheme. The OOW steered aft of the three ships and laid the Finnsailor on a parallel course between the northernmost ship and the one in the middle.  In his mind all three ships would continue in the direction of the separation lane and turn where the direction changes from approximately east-west to approximately northeast-southwest.  The southernmost of the four ships, the General Grot-Rowecki began to turn to port in order to continue along the new running of the separation lane.  The new course pointed in the front of the stem of the second southernmost ship, Dana 1, which was forced to turn also to port.  Since the attention of the OOW of Finnsailor was completely focused on the northernmost ship, Protector, he did not notice until late that the General Grot-Rowecki had turned to port with her course in front of the stem.  When Finnsailor realised that a hazardous close-quarters situation was a fact, the OOW tried to turn away by hard to port rudder.  The manoeuvre failed and the starboard quarter of the Finnsailor hit the port side of the General Grot-Rowecki in way of hatch no. 6.  The hulls of the two ships were seriously damaged and both had to proceed to a shipyard for repairs.

On 31 October 2005 at 12.00 hours LT the MT AKADEMIK VERESHCHAGIN dropped anchor at the No 5A anchorage off Saint Petersburg for loading in a ship to ship operation from the vessel MT UNITED SUNRISE, Monrovia flagged.  The vessel was in ballast. On 04 November 2006 at 11.55 hours LT, the vessel made fast with her port side alongside the starboard side of the MT UNITED SUNRISE, with five pneumatic fenders between the vessels. At 13.45 hours LT the loading hoses were connected and the loading of the cargo of VGO commenced.Wind was blowing at force 3, the sea was smooth, air temperature measured 4 degrees Celsius and the sea temperature was recorded 8 degrees Celsius. At 22.00 hours LT, the accommodation ladder of the MT UNITED SUNRISE was lowered down to the level of the deck of the MT AKADEMIK VERESHCHAGIN.  As the gangway platform was some metres away from the deck of the MT AKADEMIK VERESHCHAGIN’s deck, a gangway was rigged from the accommodation ladder’s platform to the main deck of the MT AKADEMIK VERESHCHAGIN to allow the cargo surveyors to board the vessel and carry out the cargo inspection surveys.  On 04 November 2005, at 22.00 hours LT when the accommodation ladder/gangway were rigged, the safety net was not put in place around the gangway arrangement.  The chief mate decided to leave the rigging up of the safety net until after sunrise.  At around sunrise two of the mooring ropes from forward broke.  The chief mate instructed the third mate who at the time was on deck to send the bosun and two seamen to replace the broken ropes forward.  He also instructed the third mate to collect a seawater sample from the starboard side for a density test and to bring the sample to the control room.  Afterwards he was to go to the poop and check the aft ropes and later on to supervise the rigging of the safety net around the accommodation ladder/gangway set up.  While the chief mate was in the control room at 08.25 hours LT on 05 November 2005, he saw the third mate going in the direction of the port side and he contacted the third mate via the VHF sets and instructed him not to go over to the accommodation ladder platform.  An able seaman who was taking the ullage of one of the port cargo tanks near the gangway contacted the chief mate via VHF and alarmed him that the tank was 95% full.  The chief mate moved away from the window to cancel the alarm on the port tank and when he looked out again he could not see the third mate and he noticed that the gangway was in a tilted position.  As he could not see third mate, the chief mate contacted the able seaman via VHF and asked him the whereabouts of the third mate.  At the same time, the chief mate saw the able seaman running to the port side with a life buoy and throwing it into the sea between the two vessels.  The chief mate ran out of the control room to the area near the gangway and saw the third mate face up in the water between the two vessels, hanging on to one of the fender chains.The man overboard alarm was raised and the crew members tried to recover the third mate from the water.  Nevertheless, after some time, the third mate was noticed to sink below the surface of the water.The local authorities were informed and about an hour later a search was organised for the missing person.  At 12.15 hours LT on November 5th 2005, the search was suspended and divers could not be utilised to search for the missing person due to the heavy seas.The third mate’s body was never recovered.

SummaryOfEvents: On 22nd October 2005 the 58m oil tanker HUMBER PRINCESS had unloaded her cargo at an oil terminal, and was then directed to a layby berth in a nearby dock. As the vessel arrived at the lock entrance, the dock master asked the master to hold off a bullnose to allow an outbound vessel to clear the lock, and the master then proceeded to land the vessel on the bullnose as is the usual procedure. However, the vessel landed heavily on the bullnose, unwittingly striking a bracket underwater which had become detached from the bullnose, causing two 30mm punctured holes in a starboard cargo tank.  Upon realising the vessel was leaking product, the master drove the vessel into the dock, and the dockmaster closed the gates to contain the pollution. A contractor was sourced to recover the estimated 250 litres of oil spilled, and the contents of the damaged cargo tank was transferred to other tanks. The damaged tank was then ventilated and the holes plugged with broom handles prior to a 600mm x 600mm insert plate being fitted to the hull. Most of the oil was recovered by the contractor, with the remainder dispersed by the elements. Following the accident, the port authority inspected the bullnose and noted that a fender had previously been removed for repair, exposing a bracket/lug underwater; these were subsequently burnt off down to the low water spring mark, with no further obstruction found. The authority decided that no unfendered single skin vessels were to use this bullnose, with a long term review to be conducted of fendering requirements.

Earlier in the month of the accident, following another unrelated incident, the second and third engineers dismantled and inspected the winch brake on the starboard lifeboat davit of this container vessel.  Later she was en route between Charleston and Houston USA when a scheduled fire and boat drill was carried out.  Prior to a lifeboat being lowered a debrief took place.   The starboard lifeboat was then swung out without incident.  The boat was then lowered, the brake would not hold and the boat continued to lower towards the water.  The master put the engine telegraph to stop.  Despite putting weight on the brake handle the brake was not able to stop the boat lowering into the water.  Despite the ship's forward motion, the boat was held by the painter and the two falls.  The electric winch control was connected and the boat began to be recovered.  When it was 2m from "home" the winch failed and the boat once again lowered to the water.  This time there was considerable slack in the falls and eventually the forward falls released, the painter pulled out from its securing point and the after falls disconnected.  The life
boat was lost as it was too dangerous to launch the other lifeboat in order to effect a recovery. Subsequent examination concluded that the starboard lifeboat winch brake had been incorrectly set after being inspected (it was not tested after the maintenance) and that, in all probability, the falls must have been set to relases before the boat was lowered.

Then, in order to reduce the draught, the crew began to pump the water of the ballast tanks. Gradually some leakages in the tank system of Doria were detected which involved a minor water ingress and the corresponding spillages of oil and harmful substances.
At about 04:00 on 21 October 2005, Doria managed to get clear of the shoal under her own power and continued her voyage, as agreed with the ship operator and the classification society.
During the following days on sea, soundings were taken at regular intervals, and tanks were opened as far as possible. In this connection it became obvious that the extent of the damages to the underwater hull had to be greater than initially had been assumed.
 After several inquiries with various shipyards were unsuccessful, a shipyard in Durban (Republic of South Africa) could be booked for an inspection of the underwater hull and any repairs that might prove necessary.
There Doria was docked after a previous discharge of the container cargo on 01 November 2005.

In the afternoon of 14 October 2005 the six metre Department of Immigration and
Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) vessel Malu Sara was returning from Saibai
Island at the northern extreme of the Torres Strait to its home community on Badu Island.
During the mid afternoon, the skipper reported that he was lost in reduced visibility. There were
five people on board: the two male DIMIA crew, two adult females and a four year old girl.
There was no suggestion of panic or distress. With the onset of darkness, at about 1915 on
14 October, the Thursday Island Police took over coordination of the search for Malu Sara. The
skipper was instructed to activate the boat’s emergency position indicating radio beacon and
the boat’s position was eventually established. Later the skipper reported that he was close to
an island and could see a shore light. It appeared that Malu Sara was in a sheltered position. At
0215 the skipper again made contact by satellite telephone and reported that the boat was taking
on water and sinking.
Despite an extensive search over six days, involving the Queensland Police Service and the
Australian Maritime Safety Authority’s Rescue Coordination Centre, no trace of the boat was
found. The body of one of the females on board was recovered by Indonesian fishermen near
Deelder Reef about 50 nautical miles west of Malu Sara’s last known position and landed to
Indonesian authorities. The body was subsequently repatriated to Australia for burial.

On 27th September 2005 the cargo ship REGINA BALTICA experienced a failure to its electrical power-supply system (generators produced low voltage current).
The main engines and steering gear were stopped, and the left anchor was let go. However, the winds and current led the ship to run aground, resulting in a penetrating hole to the forepeak.  A forced blackout was created in order to restore electrical power distribution.
Assessment of loss of draft (rudder and propellers were free in water).
Ballast water was pumped out of foretanks.
The ship was refloated with engines astern movement and proceeded to the nearest port being assisted by another passenger ship of the same company.

SummaryOfEvents: On  26 September 2005 at approximately 19.02 ours LT, the container ship CAST PROSPERITY and the tanker HYDE PARK collided during an overtaking manoeuvre in the dredged channel in Lac Saint-Pierre, approximately 12 nautical miles southwest of Trois-Rivières, Quebec. Both ships sustained considerable damage but were able to proceed to Montréal, Québec, without assistance or further incident. No injuries or pollution were reported.

On 24 September 2005, the Canadian Leader departed Pointe-Noire, Québec, fully loaded with iron ore pellets and bound for Hamilton, Ontario. At 01:15 eastern daylight time on September 26, upstream of Deschaillons-sur-Saint-Laurent, Quebec, the vessel sustained a blackout. With the helm no longer responsive, the ship took a sheer to starboard and ran aground near buoy D38.
Water ingress was observed in the forepeak and the No 1 starboard   ballast tank. Three hours later, on a rising tide, two unsuccessful attempts to refloat were made.
Later that morning, the crew realized that the cargo hold was taking in water and, once the vessel’s management company was apprised of the situation, a salvage tug and equipment were requested. Upon arrival, portable pumps were rigged and de-watering commenced. At approximately 05:25 on September 28, the third attempt to refloat was successful. The ship then proceeded to the port of Quebec, where it was partially unloaded and underwent temporary repairs. Afterward, she resumed its voyage toward the Great Lakes.

On 20th September 2005, during extremely high tides,  the container vessel FOWAIRET was unable to keep her course at the passage of Schaar van Ossenisse, which resulted in grounding.

Normal currents are weaker and much more along the direction of sailing channel.

YIOMARAL departed, fully loaded, from an anchorage at Aalbæk Bugt to pass North of Skagen bound for Las Palmas.

Appr. the hours later a crank case explosion occurred in the main engine, a 7-cylinder two-stroke Sulzer diesel engine. The ship lost its propulsion and maneouvrability and had to anchor again.

Investigations showed that the crank case explosions was caused by a burned hole in a piston crown. The hole had the size of a medium-large coin.

Via this hole there was created connection between the combustion chamber of the cylinder and the piston's cooling oil channel and further to the engine's crank case.

All relief valves of the engine were lifted by the explosion, but no fire broke in the engine room.

At 0736 (UTC) on 17 September 2005, the Swedish registered oil/chemical tanker BRO TRAVELLER ran aground in Dublin Bay, following passage from Pembroke.  The grounding occurred in the fairway to Dublin Bay with a harbour pilot on board.  As the ship approached the Dublin Bay buoy the pilot boarded west of Dublin Bay buoy and the vessel proceeded with about 5-6 knots, as another ship was to pass the BRO TRAVELLER.  Due to a strong north westerly tide the vessel drifted outside the fairway channel and run aground.
The vessel was re-floated (without outside assistance) after 55 minutes and proceeded to her discharge berth.  The ship was carrying 10982 tonnes of Irish gas oil. 
No damage occurred to the vessel, and there was no pollution.

At about 1630 on 15 September 2005, a fire broke out in the engine room workshop on board the bulk carrier OPAL NAREE.
A fitter had been allocated the task of weld repairing the sewage system save-all base, while the duty oiler was assigned to standby in the workshop below and keep a fire watch.  The oiler left the workshop to answer the telephone, and then attended to a ballast pump fault that the second mate had alerted him to.  During this time the fitter continued to work, and it appears that molten metal from the welding process fell into the workshop, landing on coiled electrical cables, causing them to ignite.
The fire was detected by the fitter and the emergency alarm was raised.  The crew mustered and the Master contacted the port authority, who, in turn contacted the fire and emergency services.
The crew closed all the engine room doors and fire dampers while the Master and Chief engineer assessed the situation.  They decided to use the fixed fire extinguishing system, and at 1700 carbon dioxide was released into the engine room.
By 1800 two fire fighting tugs were standing by the ship and the fire and emergency services authority (FESA) were on board.  At 2153 the ship's crew and FESA commenced the first of two inspections of the engine room.  There was no sign of fire and by 2310 the ship's crew had begun ventilating the engine room.

On September 15th 2005 at approximately 15.53 hours LT the Liberian-flagged container vessel the CCNI TOKYO was involved in a collision with the fishing vessel YASMY while transiting the Folgo de Gyayaquil. The CCNI TOKYO hit the fishing vessel's port quarter area, and as a result the fishing boat sank. The four crew members of the fishing boat were immediately taken on board the CCNI TOKYO, which proceeded back to Guayaquil, where the crew of the fishing boat disembarked. Following the local authority investigation the CCNI TOKYO resumed its voyage. Whilst the CCNI TOKYO sustained very little structural damage and there were no injuries to crew, the fishing vessel sank and one crew member required medical assistance. Flag state investigation was conducted by obtaining the flag state report and follow-up communications for clarification after review, as necessary.

The bulk carrier, m/v SHAN HAI, was alongside 'A' Shed in the port of Durban on 15 September 2005, loading steel products.
At about 05:10, while lifting two steel coils, the topping lift wire of number 1 crane parted, the jib fell and the head of the jib struck the cargo hook block.
The lever action of the jib system caused the crane to topple off its mountings and crash to the deck.
The crane operator was trapped in the cabin under the crane and fatally crushed.

On 12th September 2005 the MV LEADER 1 sailed from Japan in ballast bound for the port of Incheon, South Korea, to load a cargo of steel and bagged cargo. On 12 September 2005 at 03.26 hours LT, about 20 miles south of Cheyudo Islands, the vessel collided with the fishing boat 2003 DAEJIN, registered in Seoguipo, South Korea. The second mate and an able seaman were on the bridge of the MV LEADER 1.  The vessel was navigating through a very busy area where numerous fishing boats were operating.  The second mate was monitoring one of these fishing boats, which was on his starboard bow on a reciprocal course and was sure that she would pass clear of his vessel on his starboard side. When the fishing boat was about 1 Nm away from the vessel, she stopped and then changed direction to her starboard and rapidly increased her speed.   The second mate tried to turn his vessel to starboard to avoid the ensuing collision.  In spite of these actions, the fishing boat made contact with the vessel’s bow and started to take in water immediately.The master, who came up on the bridge a short while after the collision, immediately informed the Search and Rescue Centre of the collision. The SAR Centre immediately commenced a search and rescue operation under the command of the South Korean Navy. About four ships, and later two helicopters, joined the search.  Some fishing vessels, which were in the vicinity, also took part in the SAR operation.The fishing boat was manned by 10 persons.  Eight crew members were rescued and one dead body was recovered.  Another crew member is still reported missing. Attempts to salvage the swamped fishing boat failed and the latter subsequently sank.

Safe Concordia is a dynamic positioning, self propelled, semi-submersible accommodation platform that uses four electrically driven thrusters to maintain its position. The platform’s construction was completed, and its delivery trials were carried, out in March 2005. 
During its voyage from Singapore to Bass Strait, Australia, the platform experienced two electrical fires in its thruster power system. On 12 September 2005, after it had entered Bass Strait, a fire started in the platform’s number four thruster transformer. On 18 September, a fire occurred in an electrical cabinet that was providing power to the number one thruster motor.
The investigation found that the transformer fire was probably the result of an internal short circuit that occurred when the insulation failed due to overheating. The cabinet fire was the result of an electrical arc that occurred because the bridging out of some electrical equipment was not adequately undertaken.
It was also considered that Safe Concordia was not fit to fulfil its charter obligations in view of the unresolved faults in the thrusters’ electrical power systems and the design of the platform did not allow for effective and safe fire fighting in the thruster rooms.
The report makes several recommendations to address these issues.

Location: Shetland Islands, 3 miles W. of Scalloway
SummaryOfEvents:
At about 2137 on 3 September 2005, the emergency towing vessel (ETV) Anglian Sovereign ran aground on the small island of Bulta Skerry, 3 miles west of Scalloway, in the Shetland Islands. There were no injuries to the crew, but the vessel was severely damaged and about 84 tonnes of gas oil were lost into the environment. 
On the day of the accident, the ETV had been tasked, in one of its secondary roles, to carry out hydrographic survey sea trials in an area between Scalloway and the island of Foula. The trials finished at 2019, and the master, who was on watch, set course for the entrance to the South Channel for Scalloway harbour. After a short hiatus for a further trial, the master resumed a similar course, although as the final trial had displaced the ETV from its previous track, the vessel was now heading towards the small island of Oxna.  It was dark, but there was no lookout posted, so the master was alone on the bridge. Passing very close to Skelda Ness, the ETV maintained a steady course at 16 knots for 17 minutes until it grounded.
The master reported the grounding to Shetland Coastguard, and requested a rescue helicopter to evacuate all of his crew, who were mustering, in their survival suits and lifejackets, on the after working deck.  There was little effort to assess the situation before deciding to evacuate the vessel.  Unnoticed by the master, the ETV had floated off where it had grounded, and then drifted some distance before coming to rest in a cleft in one of the islands of the Cheynies.
By 2240, the mustered crew were evacuated by rescue helicopter, leaving the master alone on board.  At this stage, the master decided to clutch in the main engines and drive the ETV out of the cleft into the open sea. By 2253, Anglian Sovereign was underway, listing about 15° to starboard, trimmed down by the head, and was leaking diesel oil. Subsequently the master momentarily ran aground on another island, before successfully reaching and berthing in Scalloway.
The police boarded the ETV shortly after arrival, and breathalysed the master. Finding him to be 3.4 times over the proscribed limit for alcohol, he was arrested and taken to Lerwick police station.

InitialEvent: hazardous material release during pipe work renewal - three fatalies
SummaryOfEvents:
1.1	On 2nd September 2005, two engine room crew were overcome by fumes when performing maintenance on pulper system pipe work, noxious fumes were released when pipe flanges were broken. 
1.2	Pulper systems process food waste from the ship’s galleys before it is discharged overboard. The ship had berthed that morning.
1.3	The two engine room crew were seen collapsed on the deck of the starboard shaft tunnel, just before 09:00, by the Engine Foreman who raised the alarm by phoning 911 (ship internal emergency system) reporting what he had seen and requesting assistance. The Engine Foreman returned to the scene with the First Engineer and the Inventory Technical Specialist, these three people began a rescue attempt before Emergency Teams arrived.
1.4	The initial emergency announcement was made at 09:00 as an Alpha Emergency (medical). At the start of the incident the cause of the engine room crew collapsing was not known nor was it realised that the area was still contaminated with extremely toxic fumes. 
NB The Medical Emergency Team does not respond with Self Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA).
1.5	When the Medical Emergency Team arrived at the scene, 09:02, a Bravo Emergency (fire/smoke) announcement was immediately requested and made. As the emergency progressed members of the emergency teams and rescuers became affected by the fumes. A staging area for equipment and personnel was set up away from the scene. 
1.6	Assistance was requested, by the ships Operation Control Team, to the port authority. Local emergency services, paramedics and fire department responded swiftly.
1.7	The incident resulted in 3 fatalities, one person was detained in hospital and eighteen others were treated in hospital and released the same day, some required follow up treatment.
The 3 fatalities were the two crew members who removed the pipe and the Engine Foremen who first found them. 
The First Engineer suffered a collapsed lung. 
1.8	The pulper pipe passed through an adjacent fresh water ballast tank (T7017 Dry Tank 11), sections of this pipe line were later discovered to be holed and this had allowed large quantities of food waste to accumulate in the tank. The resulting chemical reaction had caused Hydrogen Sulphide, (H2S) gas to be generated which released during the incident.
1.9	The fresh water ballast tank had previously been a void space and had been re-designated as part of a change in load line. No structural or system changes were made as part of this change of use.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

On 28 August 2005 at 2200 hrs, MT Overseas United experienced main engine problem due to damaged exhaust valve. Master was at the bridge, Chief Officer and 1 AB at the anchor station forward. Vessel safely dropped port anchor on 29 August 2005 at 0015 hrs at the abovementioned location.

The anchor lights and all lights on deck were immediately switched on after dropping of the anchor. Master noticed that there were 3 fishing boats around his vessel when anchoring. The nearest fishing boat as shown in radar screen was 3 miles away.

After anchor was brought up to 5 shackles in the water, Master handed over duty to duty officer and went down to cabin to take rest.

At about 0130hrs, Master was informed by Chief Officer that one unknown fishing boat was coming towards their vessel. The Master immediately rushed up to the bridge and instructed Chief Officer to heave up port anchor in order to keep away from fishing boat. 

At about 0145hrs, Chief Officer informed the Master that he had heaved up the anchor to 2 shackles only and was unable to heave further as the anchor's chain had entangled with the fishing nets.

In order to avoid collision, the Chief Officer started signalling the fishing boat to keep away but the fishing boat kept coming towards vessel.

At about 0205hrs, the unknown fishing boat collided onto the starboard bow area of the vessel.

After the collision, the fishing boat was still able to manoeuver and move forward of the vessel for about 75 metres ahead. The other 2 fishing boats started to transfer the crew of the fishing boat and their belongings to their vessels.

At about 0230hrs, the fishing boat started to list to the portside and slowly sank.

Location: North Sea, 40 miles N-E of Peterhead
SummaryOfEvents:
At around 1630 on 28 August 2005, the UK-registered trawler, HARVEST HOPE came fast while trawling in the vicinity of seabed pipelines, approximately 40 miles north-east of Peterhead.  The aft net drum space immediately began to flood through the port transom door, which had been inadvertently left open from the previous voyage.
A port list quickly developed, which worsened as more water poured in through the transom door.  The crew immediately tried to close the open door using the hydraulic ram, but this became damaged by a green sea, and the door could not be closed.
An electric submersible pump, located at the forward end of the net drum space, on the port side began to drain the water.  However, the pump stopped immediately after a flash was observed from the area of the pump and its junction box.  There were six non-return freeing ports, commonly known as tonnage valves, in the net drum space.  These had been welded up by the owners several years before the sinking, due to practical concerns about back-flooding.  There was no other means of clearing the rising flood water in the net drum space.
The crew witnessed water pouring into the galley through open windows in the watertight bulkhead at the forward end of the net drum space.  Water was also latterly seen flowing into the forward cabins.  A window in one of these cabins, leading forward into the fish processing space, was also known to be open, and would have allowed progressive flooding into this space.
As the port list increased, main hydraulic power was lost, resulting in the brakes on the vessel's automatic trawl winch system activating.  With no safe and easy means of releasing these brakes, the vessel was effectively anchored to the seabed on the port side.  Although the trawl warps were cut with an electric grinder, the vessel's condition failed to improve.
Despite some difficulties, the crew managed to deploy the starboard liferaft, and as the list critically increased, the crew abandoned into the liferaft, around 15 minutes after first coming fast.  Shortly afterwards, the vessel capsized, and sank by the stern. Not all crew had been able to put on their lifejackets. A nearby fishing vessel had responded to the earlier "Mayday" issued by HARVEST HOPE and safely recovered the crew.

On 22nd July 2005 the chemical tanker OCEAN BLOSSOM left QINHUNGDAO(CHINA) for NIIHAMA(JAPAN), and at 14:48 hours LT was at ballast voyage.
At the above position and time (38º36.23N, 120º53.60E, 21h-58m, 22nd July, 2005 LT), the Chinese ship was visible by 0.5 miles and duty 3/0 was checked six miles before by radar. The MT Halifax was transiting the River Elbe with a pilot onboard.  The ship was on a voyage from Ventspil to Hamburg with a cargo of gas oil.

At 00:32, the ship entered the Brunsbüttel – Hamburg section of the river transit.  At 01:23, the pilot ordered a reduction in speed to half ahead as the ship was ahead of her ETA for the Hamburg berthing pilot.

At 01:30, the second officer plotted the ship’s position abeam of Rhinplatte S light.  From this position, the ship had approximately 0.5 cables before coming abeam of port hand buoy 84 and 1.25 cables before the waypoint. Several minutes later, the pilot ordered the wheel to port 100, immediately followed with hard to port and full ahead orders.  All pilot’s ORDERS were executed, however, the ship ran aground at 01:32, heading 154.50 (T) and with buoy 85a approximately on the port beam. Following the grounding and preliminary evaluation, various attempts were made to refloat the ship, using the main engine and the harbour tugs, but the attempts were unsuccessful due to the falling tide.  After lightning of about 1,900 metric tonnes of cargo, the ship was refloated at 13:30 on the same day.

As the fire got out of hand, it was decided to close waterfight fire doors of the Clean Power Room. The fire then exhausted by lack of oxigen. The Fire was caused by hot work. Filter catridges packed in cartons were ignited by the intense heat from the welding. 
- Human error was the primary cause fo the fire due to the ships fitter not taking elementary precautions to protect against spontaneous combustion caused by heat transfer through the bulkhead from the welding. 
- Besides, 2 hot work permits shall not be issued at the same time unless there are sufficient crew members to perform all the necessary safety precautions.

Le navire vient d’effectuer un déchargement de produits pétroliers au Japon et se présente sur ballast, selon les instructions de l’affréteur, le 14 août 2005 en rade de Dalian (Chine). Il mouille dans la zone de mouillage et de pilotage de Dalian Xingang. Pilote à bord, il se dirige vers le port pétrolier, évite, et accoste cap au Sud-Sud-Est au quai pétrolier n° 2 de Xingang Dalian.
Son chargement terminé, le navire pétrolier/transporteur de produits BRO.CHARLOTTE appareille le 16 août 2005 à 23h30, avec un chargement de 32 965,049 t d’essence sans plomb pour Djakarta en Indonésie, tirant d’eau sans différence de 10,50.m. Il manoeuvre avec l’aide de deux remorqueurs, après le contour de l’extrémité du quai, les remorques sont larguées et le pilote débarque.
Sous les ordres du capitaine, assisté de l’élève puis de l’officier de quart, le navire maintient une route plus Nord que la route tracée en raison de l’encombrement de la rade par des fermes aquacoles, des pêcheurs en pêche et des navires au mouillage. La nouvelle bordée de quart est montée à la passerelle et prend la suite du quart précédent. A minuit, le navire est mis en route libre. A 00h10, le navire s’échoue, à 10 noeuds, sur le plateau rocheux Nansanliangche Jiao, à la position 38° 57,81’ N ~ 121° 58,08’ E.
L’échouement s’étant produit à une heure proche de la marée basse, le navire a pu être remis à flot quelques heures après. Il est resté sur rade et l’armateur a fait le nécessaire pour que le chargement soit transféré sur deux autres navires dans les meilleurs délais. Le navire est alors entré en cale sèche à Dalian pour réparations. Toutes saisies conservatoires levées, il a pu reprendre la mer le 29.octobre 2005.
L’accident du BRO CHARLOTTE n’a pas provoqué de dommages aux personnes ni de pollution du milieu marin.

SOLASStatus: MORNING HARUKA: Unknown/unspecified, OTAKOU: Unknown/unspecified, PURBECK: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
At 20h20, the trawler OTAKOU observed the tanker MORNING HARUKA approaching on her starboard bow at a range of approximately 7.5 miles.  Her ARPA gave a CPA of 0.3 miles.  Attempts by OTAKOU to attract the attention of MORNING HARUKA by VHF radio and flashing light failed.  Consequently, OTAKOU commenced hauling her net, which reduced her speed to approximately 1 knot.  MORNING HARUKA passed ahead of OTAKU with a CPA of 0.4 miles at approximately 20h40.
Shortly after another potential close quarters situation developed between MORNING HARUKA and PURBECK. This potential close quarters situation did not exist until PURBECK's planned alteration of course at 20h58.  Eleven minutes later, at 21h09, PURBECK called MORNING HARUKA on VHF to advise of a CPA of 3 cables and to request MORNING HARUKA's intentions.  The third officer of MORNING HARUKA replied that he would alter course.  At 21h16 PURBECK advised MORNING HARUKA that he was not happy with his actions and was slowing down.  Eventually the vessels passed within 1 nautical mile of each other.

The vessel tried to turn toward portside of channel with the assistance of 3 tugs.  By 06.40 hours LT, the vessel's forward portside section was stranded between the inner and outer breakwater of starboard channel.  The Fore Peak Tank and N°1 portside ballast tank were flooded with a great deal of water.  Following a salvage operation the vessel re-floated at 09.56 hours LT on 11th August 2005.

The Behice sailed from Hong Kong at 0400 on 29 July 2005, loaded with project cargo for Kuwait stowed in the lower cargo holds, tween-decks and decks of cargo holds nos. 1 and 3 and 4,352 metric tonnes of bulk fluorspar, which were loaded inside lower cargo holds nos. 2 and 4.  The Behice was to proceed south towards the Singapore Strait, Malacca Strait, the Indian Ocean and onwards to her destinations, Kandla and Kuwait.  All ballast tanks were empty.  The weather was good, slight sea and swell, wind generally southerly force 3 to 4.

Just before 0700, the same day, the vessel rapidly developed a starboard list.  The master reduced the speed and altered course into the wind.  He also ordered two port double bottom tanks to be ballasted.  Soon after, the main engine was stopped.  The list continued to increase and at about 0720, the master sounded the emergency stations on the ship bells and whistle.

At approximately 0725, the Behice transmitted a distress signal and the crew abandoned her in the starboard lifeboat and one liferaft.  The master and the chief mate remained on the poop deck but jumped overboard after 30 minutes, just before 0800.  Helicopters and fixed wing aircrafts were dispatched from Hong Kong MRCC and all 17 crew members were air lifted and transferred to a local hospital.

The vessel was eventually sighted lightly aground on the coast of southern China on 31 July at 0400, with her cargo hold no. 4 open to the sea.

On 21 July 2005 at 2345 the reefer vessel MV GLACIER was at position 720 20’ N, 0060 11’ E (about 270 nautical miles from Norway).

The chief mate, the third mate and the bosun entered the refrigerated cargo hold to inspect the stowage of the cargo.  The bosun slipped and fell on his back loosing consciousness.  The chief mate and the third mate went to his aid and CRP was administered.  The master was informed and when he arrived on the scene, he instructed the chief mate to carry the bosun to a warmer place, as the temperature in the hold was about minus 20 degrees Celsius.

The bosun was carried to the engine control room and CPR was continued.  The master contacted Iceland and Norway RCC reporting the accident and requesting assistance.  The chief mate from the fishing trawler VILHELM boarded the GLACIER to assist in the CPR.

Some ten minutes later, Iceland RCC enquired about the accident and treatment being administered to the bosun.  After confirming the state of the bosun with the master of the GLACIER, Iceland RCC informed the master that a helicopter would not be despatched, as the symptoms indicate that the bosun had passed away.

At 0100, the master confirmed that the bosun had passed away.

On 22 July 2005, at about 0510, the Japanese vessel MV Kaishin Maru and the MV Wei Hang 9 collided approximately 10.5 nautical miles south-south west of the Inubosaki Cape, within Japanese territorial waters. Reportedly, the fore end of the MV Kaishin Maru collided at right angles with the Maltese vessel, approximately at right angles and on starboard side amidships. The vessel lost its reserve buoyancy and sank in a depth of about 42-45 m within minutes of the collision.  SAR operations were immediately co-ordinated by the Japan Coast Guard and were terminated on Sunday 24 July 2005.

From a crew compliment of 21, four crew members lost their lives, whilst other five were still reported missing when the SAR operations were terminated.

On 11th July 2005 the ro-ro cargo ferry NORMAN SPIRIT was in the English channel on a night crossing to France. A male passenger on board left the bar with some friends and went onto the upper deck. He then unexpectedly climbed onto the ship's railings and placed both legs onto the outboard side. The passenger then appeared to lose his grip and fell overboard at approximately 01.45 hours LT.  A crew member in the bar was alerted and a lifebuoy with a light attached was thrown overboard by one of the passenger's friends. The OOW was informed by telephone of the accident. He recorded the ship's position using the GPS MOB facility and launched the starboard MOB marker buoy. The master was notified and the appropriate crew alert signal made. After the master arrived on the bridge a Williamson turn was started. The coastguard were notified, which commenced relaying a PAN message, and the ship's FRC were made ready but not launched as it was decided they would not help in the search (due to low height of eye). The ship commenced a search for the passenger in the water at a speed of 7 kts using searchlights and outboard lighting and was later assisted by nearby warships (one of which was nominated as the OSC). A parallel search pattern was then established. About 2.5 hours after the passenger fell overboard, a helicopter sighted a body in the water. The body was recovered and transferred to a warship, but was declared dead. The body was landed later the same day.
