Location: Lough Dergh, North of Ballina, Co Tipperary
SummaryOfEvents: On 9 July 2005 at approximately 17:00 hours,  the Class V passenger ship Ke-Ee-Tu departed from Dromineer, Co. Tipperary carrying 36 passengers and 3 crew and proceeded out onto Lough Derg. At some time between 18:30 hours and 18:45 hours whilst in the vicinity of Ryneduff Point  Co. Tipperary, a man fell overboard from the ship. Despite efforts by those onboard the ship to assist him, he was seen to sink from view shortly after. The body of Mr Dalton was recovered from the Lough in the same vicinity on 15 July 2005.

The MV QINGDAO STAR dropped anchor at Hong Kong Anchorage No. 2 on 08 July 2005 at 16.30 hours LT.  Two derrick lighters were moored alongside the vessel on each side, and cargo operations commenced at 18.48 hours.  The weather was fine with a south-easterly, light to gentle breeze. On 09th July 2005 in the afternoon, the starboard derrick lighter was unloading containers from the No.4 hold and positioning them on the containers stacked two tiers high on the deck at bay 28.  These containers were then offloaded by the port side lighter.  Two stevedores were on top of the container stacks to hook/unhook the four wire slings of the derricks into each container as necessary.  At 15.40 hours, the second mate, who was on the port side of the main deck watching the operations, observed a twenty-foot container being lowered on top of the other containers stacked on deck.  After the two stevedores disconnected the slings from the container, the crane swung clear over to the starboard side.  The second mate then observed the derrick of the port lighter swing towards the container at a relatively fast speed.  One of the legs of the lifting slings caught on the corner of the twenty-foot container, which caused the other slings to begin to spin, wrapping themselves around the fouled leg.  The sling came free and swung rapidly towards the stern. The two stevedores, who were not in the line of sight of the second mate, were climbing down to the main deck.  One of the two had already climbed down from the aft end of the container and was walking away when he heard a loud noise behind him.  On turning around, he saw his colleague lying on the main deck.The Hong Kong authorities were notified of the accident.  The injured stevedore was transferred to the forecastle deck and assisted by the vessel’s crew members.  At 16.20 hours a rescue helicopter arrived near the vessel and a doctor was lowered onto the vessel.  The injured stevedore was evacuated by helicopter at 16.44 hours to the Eastern Hospital, where he was pronounced dead.

On the morning of 08 July 2005, several ratings were instructed to carry out maintenance work on the main deck and the deck cranes.

At around 0955, the bosun instructed the other ratings to proceed to the mess room for the morning break.  One ordinary seaman missed the grip whilst going down the no.4 deck crane ladder and fell on the main deck from an approximate height of three metres.  On impact, the ordinary seaman hit his head and neck against the forward access hatch to cargo hold no. 5.  Although he was administered first aid, the ordinary seaman passed away shortly afterwards

The Blankenese was on a voyage from Riga to Rotterdam, loaded with 4,412 tonnes of wood pellets in bulk.

On 06 July 2005, at around 1800, the vessel stopped at sea in order to perform a familiarisation boat drill with all the crew members.  The intention was to lower the starboard lifeboat into the water.  All crew members, except for the master were mustered on the starboard boat deck.

The chief officer explained the duties of each individual crew member, including all the aspects of the launching procedures and the function of the safety locking pin of the on-load release mechanism.

Following the explanation, the lifeboat was checked and the boat was swung out of its stowed position on the davits.  At this time, the chief engineer and the second mate were inside the lifeboat.

When the lifeboat was at a height of about 1.5 m from the embarkation deck, the forward and aft hooks opened inadvertently and the boat dropped into the sea from a height of about  nine metres.  The second mate was quick enough to grab one of the lifelines and was helped back on board.  The chief engineer fell with the lifeboat into the water and sustained severe spinal injuries.

On 5th July 2005 at 23.05 hours LT, when both ships were on anchor at Frederikshavn, and whilst one ship was discharging gas oil to the other, a fire broke out in the engine room.
The fire was largely extinguished by the ship's crew using the CO2 plant.

The fire brigade from  Frederikshavn was brought to the ship to completely extinguish the fire.

The fire was caused by hot fuel oil spraying from a leakage on an auxiliary engine. The oil hit some live power cables which then melted, causing the fuel oil to be sprayed.
On 4th July 2005 at  07.49 hours LT, the vessel M/V: "MARBLUE" came into contact with the M/V "BENTE KOSAN" at the East OPL Anchorage in Singapore, at position Lat: 01º 17.9 N and Long: 104º 10.4 E.

AT about 14:30 hours on 2 July 2005, the sailing dinghy Mollyanna capsized 7 cables off Puffin Island, North Wales. Onboard were its owner, his son, and his two grandsons. After capsizing, the owner son tried to right the dinghy, which had inverted. Despite the wind strength of forces 5 to 6 and a wave height of about 1.5 m, he twice successfully rotated the boat upright, but it quickly capsized, inverting again on both occasions. The dinghy’s owners died about 10 minutes after the initial capsize. His son and two grand children were able to hold onto the up-turned hull, and at 15:58 hours, were seen by a passing charter fishing boat. The crew of the dinghy were recovered onboard the fishing ship. Both children were taken to hospital by helicopter, but the youngest child was pronounced dead on arrival. The deceased owner and his son were taken to Beaumaris by an RNLI lifeboat, and the charter fishing ship respectively. The dinghy, which could not be righted by RNLI personnel, was towed to Beaumaris and beached
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

Location: 5.5 miles N.E. of Portavogie, Northern Ireland
SummaryOfEvents:
The fishing vessel AURIGA capsized and sank about 6 miles north-east of Portavogie.  The Skipper and his crewman were both rescued from the stricken vessel's liferaft.  Sea conditions at the time were light SSE winds.
AURIGA was 3 hours into her second tow when she slowed down. It was felt that possibly a trawl door had dropped, but when attempts to rectify this showed no increase in the vessel's speed, it left the crew with little option other than to haul the gear.
As the trawl wires were hove in, it became apparent that there was an abnormal weight in, or on, the gear. Slowly, recovery of the net continued.
To take the strain off the gear, the Skipper put the vessel into neutral; once in neutral the vessel started to fall off the wind and, as this happened, the weight of the net, suspended from the gantry, affected the vessel's transverse stability, resulting in a dramatic list.
Recognising their perilous situation, the crew abandoned to their liferaft, without having time to transmit a distress or don lifejackets.  Fortunately, AURIGA's EPIRB floated free as the vessel sank and after about an hour in their liferaft, AURIGA's crew were rescued by a passing container ship whose watchkeeper spotted their pinpoint flare.

InitialEvent: loss of propulsion and reduction of steerage
SummaryOfEvents: At approximately 10:08 on 30 June 2005, while approaching berth No.1 at Horseshoe Bay, the Queen of Oak Bay suffered loss of propulsion and a reduction of steerage. As a result, the vessel deviated off course and struck 28 pleasure craft berthed in the adjacent marina before running aground. There were no casualties; however, there was considerable damage to the pleasure craft and marina.

Location: Off Savary Island, Northern Georgia Strait, B.C.
SummaryOfEvents: On 29 June 2005, at about 1640 Pacific daylight time, while en route from the Queen Charlotte Strait to Gibsons, British Columbia, on the Sunshine Coast, the small fishing vessel MORNING SUNRISE, with 500 prawn traps on deck and approximately 4500kg of frozen prawns in boxes in the freezer hold, listed heavily to port and gradually sank in 152m of water.  All four crew members on board, wearing immersions suits, abandoned the vessel into a liferaft and were soon picked by a Canadian Coast Guard cutter.

ON 29TH JUNE 2005 THE VESSEL WAS DEPARTING ANTWERP AND BOUND FOR BREMERHAVEN, IN THE RIVER PASSAGE WITH PILOT ON BOARD.  CPP M/E WAS ON BRIDGE CONTROL AND VESSEL WAS PROCEEDING ON FULL AHEAD MANEUVERING SPEED.  SHIP'S SPEED WAS ABOUT 15 KNOTS.  WHILE ON A COURSE OF 199 DEGREES TRUE, AT ABOUT 12.04 LT SOME VIBRATIONS WERE FELT AND C/E CALLED BRIDGE TO INQUIRE WHY THE RPM WAS INCREASED.  WHILE 2/O INFORMED THAT THE TELEGRAPH HAS NOT BEEN TOUCHED, THE VIBRATIONS INCREASED AND ALSO THE M/R RPM.  AFTER CONSULTING PILOT, THE PITCH WAS REDUCED TO SLOW AHEAD, BUT IT WAS OBSERVED THAT THE VIBRATIONS AND M/E RPM WERE FURTHER INCREASING TO OVER 160. THE PITCH WAS BROUGHT TO ZERO.  SOON AFTER THAT C/E STOPPED M/E AND STATED HE WOULD RE-START IN 5 MINUTES.  AT THAT MOMENT, THE WIND WAS SLOW, ABOUT FORCE 4 ON BEAUFORD SCALE.  TIDE WAS EBBING OUT, PUSHING VESSEL FROM ASTERN.  IMMEDIATELY ANCHOR STATIONS WERE CALLED.  SHIP'S HEAD WAS SWINGING VERY RAPIDLY TO PORT, POSSIBLY DUE TO COMBINED EFFECT OF WINDS ON STARBOARD BOW, CURRENT ON PORT QUARTER AND BANK EFFECT.  AT 12.10 LT, KEEPING IN MIND THE PRESENCE OF A SUBMARINE CABLE CROSSING THE CHANNEL IN CLOSE PROXIMITY ON STABOARD SIDE, THE PORT ANCHOR WAS LET GO TO 1 SHACKLE.  SHIP'S SPEED WAS ABOUT 7 KNOTS AT THIS TIME.   SHIP CONTINUED TURNING TO PORT, FINALLY HALTING ON A HEADING OF 051 DEGREES TRUE.  SHIP'S SPEED REDUCED FROM 4 KNOTS TO ZERO VERY RAPIDLY.  AT ABOUT 12.15 LT, IT WAS APPARENT THAT VESSEL HAD RUN AGROUND IN POSITION LAT:51 DEGREES 22.783 MINUTES NORTH, 003 DEGREES 57.195 MINUTES EAST.  THE POSITION WHERE VESSEL GROUNDED WAS 1.8 CABLES OUT OF THE BUOYED CHANNEL ON THE PORT SIDE (BUOYS g 33 N 35) AND 2.9 CABLES FROM THE CHARTED COURSE LINE.

On the afternoon of 27 June 2005, the ro-ro passenger ferry CONFEDERATION with 114 people on board departed Caribou, Nova Scotia, for Wood Islands, Prince Edward Island.  The voyage was uneventful until the vessel was making preparations to dock at Wood Islands, when a crew member was discovered trapped in a watertight door.  The crew member was quickly freed from the door and subsequently transported to hospital for treatment.

Yp, Jorge Paz Perez, capitan de la M/N CHUBASCO V , siendo atracada la moto nave el dia 27 de junio a las 14:00 horas en el muelle No / del puerto de Cristobal.

Se empiesa el cargue el dia 28 de junio a las 12:00 hrs y terminando a las 21:45 hrs.

El dia 29 de junio se empezo el cargue a las 12:00 hrs y se termino a las 23:30 hrs quedando todo en optimas condiciones, de tal forma que los marinos procedieron a colocar las carpas para tapar y las cuales se amararian el dia siguiente, pero siendo las 02:30 hrs nos percatamos que la embarcacion se inclino al laso de estribor llemdose a tierra sobre el muelle / en Cristobal, y desconociendo las consecuencias que sobre vendrian.

Procedi como capitan a informarle al jefe de operaciones el Sr. Carlos Freile, llego al lugar de los hechos y percatandose de lo sucedido, salio en busca del Gerente General de la Naviera, para tomar las desiciones sobre el caso, fue entonces cuando el Sr. Kaled Ajram autorizo de inmediato a cortar las carpas y las cabullas para tratar de estabilizar la nave. Procediendo a buscar la cuadrilla de descargue para evacuar la carga que se encontraba sobre el pillote, labor que se realizo durante todo el dia.

Las 19:00 hrs nos dimos cuenta que salia humo de la bodega No 1, llamando de inmediatamente al cuerpo de bomberos, el cual se hizo presente al mando del Sargento Catalino Lam con su personal y equipo. Se procedio a remolcar el barco hacia la punta del muelle donde siendo las 11:00 hrs aproximadamente fue imposible evitar el hundimiento de la nave.

On executing a starboard turn the OOW miscalculated the turning circle and executed the turn too late and used too little rudder angle. The vessel grounded north of the DW route. SOLASStatus: China Steel Growth: Unknown/unspecified, CHINA STEEL GROWTH: Unknown/unspecified, PILSUM: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
At 09.39 hours on 24 June 2005, the bulk carrier PILSUM collided with another bulk carrier, China Steel
Growth, while dragging its anchor. The two ships were anchored off the New South Wales port
of Newcastle.

On the morning of 24 June, a southerly weather front came through the anchorage. At 09.00 hours LT on
24 June, the officer of the watch on Pilsum detected that the ship was dragging its anchor. The
master was informed and he decided to weigh anchor and depart the anchorage.

Pilsum’s crew encountered difficulties recovering the anchor. During the anchor retrieval
process Pilsum drifted towards China Steel Growth, which was anchored to the north.

At 09.35 hours LT PILSUM pitched heavily, the propeller came clear of the water and the main engine was
shut down by the overspeed trip. PILSUM'S main engine was restarted, but at 09.39 hours LT, she
collided with China Steel Growth. The two ships moved apart and then made contact a second
time before PILSUM  finally made its way clear.

At 14.00 hours LT on 22nd June 2005 a fire broke out in the engine room of side trawler JOHANNES during fishing. The fire detector had not sounded, but poor fire fighting methods were used as well: part of the ventilation system was not closed, no boundary cooling applied, activation of Quick Closing Valve initially "forgotten". The crew thought they had activated the Halon system, but they had not, nor were portable fire fighting appliances used. The crew were saved by surrounding vessels.

Location: OFF POND MOUTH BEACON ABOUT 0.12N.M KINGSTON
SummaryOfEvents:
At 22.19 hours LT on June 19 2005 the general cargo ship BALSA 54 arrived at Kingston pilot station laden with 5,991.191MT of yellow corn and soybean meal in bulk cargo leaded at Norfolk, Virginia for Kingston, Jamaica discharge, with the draft of 6.80M (SW)even Keel as the port limit draft allowed for Kingston, Jamaica. At 22.24 hours LT pilot Capt. N. Saunderson boarded our vessel and at 23.19 hours LT dropped her starboard anchor up to four shackles in the water at Alpha anchorage Kingston inner harbour, waiting for day break to come alongside berth, and at 23.28 hours LT the pilot was off.
At 06.19 hours LT on June 20, 2005 the starboard anchor was being hauled up,  as ordered by the proceeding pilot to the vessel through VHF ch 11, and at 06.27 hours LT pilot Capt. N. Saunderson and an apprentice pilot Mr. W Dison boarded the vessel. At 06.30 hours LT standby engine and answered for maneuvers to come alongside berth Wherry wharf. At 06.36 hours LT starboard anchor was aweigh and followed by various bells. At about 06.49 hours Pond Mouth beacon was abeam on ship starboard side on course 290 degrees. With about a distance of 0.13 N.M and the engine stop, vessel moving ahead due to momentum, vessel course altered slowly rounding Pond Mouth beacon passing said beacon at about 06.50 hours and about 0.10 N.M. distance on our starboard beam vessel heading 340 degrees. At about 06.51 hours dead slow ahead engine ordered but the vessel had run aground.
At about 06.51 hours the engine was stopped. VESSEL AGROUND IN POSITION LAT 17 DEG 57.83 mim NORTH AND LONG 076 DEG 48.75 mim WEST DISTANCE OFF THE POND MOUTH BEACON ABOUT 0.12 N.M.

Immediately ordered sounding around the vessel be taken, double bottom tanks and cargo hold bilges and found cargo hold bilges empty, double bottom tanks non increase in soundings. Soundings taken around the vessel, on the bow along center line 5.00 M, draft fore castle portsid 6.80 M, starboard side 5.80 M, at midship on plimsoll mark port side 8.30 M starboardside 7.40 M, along N0.3 after part port side 9.00 M, starboard side 8.50 M and at astern 9.00m.
Bottom was soft mud except on the extreme bow. Pumping out of forepeak tank and pumping in WBT 3 Port & Starboard was ordered and paid out for shackles in the water on both anchors to lighten up trimming vessel. At 10.04 hours the tug Palisadoes made fast astern to assist the vessel in clearing the ground, with our vessel main engine on full astern, but still to no avail. At 10.50 hours tug line was let go and at 11.10 hours main Engine was stopped. At about 11.11 hours ordered full astern of the Main engine followd by various bells of the Main Engine on full astern but still to no avail. Vessel remained stuck aground.

METRES IN LENGTH AND 3 METRES IN WIDTH, LEAVING THE RUBBER FENDER SLIGHTLY DAMAGED. VESSEL BOW DENTED 2.8 METRES X 2.8 METRES X 2.8 METRES AND A HOLE ABOUT 0.5 METRE ABOVE WATER LINE.

The port lifeboat was prepared for launching while berthed at Setubal with five crew inside.  The on-load release gear malfunctioned resulting in premature release of the aft suspension hook.  The lifeboat then swung towards a vertical position suspended under the forward hook.  The forward hook then failed and the boat fell stern first into the water.  The boat floated inverted with the crew trapped inside.  Efforts to rescue the trapped crew began immediately and were successful in bringing three crew out of the boat.  The two remaining crew could not be rescued and were found to be dead when the boat was later lifted using a crane.
The investigation identified risks associated with on-load release gear on lifeboats and makes recommendations to improve the safety of crew during practice and emergency launching of lifeboats with on-load release equipment.

At about 22:50 on June 2005, in good weather conditions, the rented pleasure craft Quintana Roo cast off from the public Wharf at Kelowna, British Columbia, with a total of 61 persons on board: 55 on the upper deck, and 6 inside the lower accommodation area. Minutes after leaving its berth, the ship listed to port and rapidly capsized. Many persons jumped or fell of and some, together with members of the public, helped to rescue those trapped inside. Some suffered minor injuries, and one person succumbed later, in hospital

Location: South West of East London, South Africa
SummaryOfEvents:
The MV KIPEROUSA sailed from Port Gentil, Gabon on 28 May 2005 at 2130 LT, loaded with a cargo of 23,094 mt of logs, bound for China via Durban.
On 07 June 2005, when about 33 Nm south west of East London, South Africa and 1.2 Nm off the shore line, the vessel struck the seabed.  The engine room started flooding and the main engine stopped.
The master carried out a damage assessment.  Without its main engine, the vessel was now drifting south with the current.  After about two to three hours, the wind changed direction and the vessel started to drift towards the shore.  The water level in the engine room was still rising and the master realised that the rate of water ingress was more than the pumping capacity of the pumps.  The master instructed the chief mate to drop the starboard anchor.  A National Sea Rescue Institute (NRSI) boat arrived and one official boarded the vessel.  The master spoke with the owners and the official that had boarded the vessel was asked to disembark.  Some time later, a helicopter hovered over the vessel and two surveyors and one border police were winched down on the vessel.  At 1930 a tugboat arrived on the scene, but the master of the vessel, as instructed by the owners, opted to do without assistance.
At about 1800, the vessel started pounding by the stern and listed between five to ten degrees to starboard.  The master and crew abandoned the vessel in the lifeboats and were rescued by the tugboat. 
The crew members were transferred to East London.

On 5th June 2005 at 04.00 hours LT the bulk carrier ELEFTHERIA, with at draught of 12.8 meters, was northbound in route-tango in the Great Belt and was approaching the junction point of route-tango and route-hotel off Agersoe Flak. A tanker with a DW of 34,761 was approaching the same point in route-hotel - also northbound. At the same time another tanker with a DW of 115,000 was southbound and approaching the narrow channel north of the junction point. The two northbound ships turned at the junction point at approx. the same time. The bulk carrier close to the centre of the route, and the tanker to the outermost limit (to the East) of the route.         
After having observed the oncoming (southbound) tanker the OOW on the bulk carrier altered the course to port in order to avoid a collision and the ship grounded outside and west of the route.

On 04 Jun 05, the MV “Everise Glory” (EG)13519 GT bulk carrier, while approaching the Middle Channel (Eastern approaches to the Singapore Strait Traffic Separation Scheme (TSS) ) collided with  MV “Uni Concord” (UC) 12405 GT feeder container vessel. UC and EG were in a crossing situation with EG on the starboard bow of UC. The collision occurred at about 1139 hours on 4 Jun 05 about 14 Km northeast of Horsburgh Lighthouse.

The bow of UC penetrated EG’s port amidships area. EG sank soon after the ships separated. Some of the crewmembers of EG jumped into the sea and others abandoned the ship into the life raft. A total of 23 crewmembers out of 24 were rescued by a fishing trawler. After about two hours a Singapopre Navy ship and two coastguard boats arrived at the scene and the rescued crewmembers were brought ashore. Five crewmembers had suffered minor injuries. The chief officer from EG is still missing. The search for the missing crewmember was called off on 7 Jun 0 05. 

None of the crew of UC was injured. There was slight fuel oil leakage from UC. After arresting fuel oil leak UC was brought to Singapore for temporary repairs.
Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Loss of life

These barges were being towed by the tug Ocean Warrior. Unable to get clear of the towline, the fishing ship was struck and holed by barge 216. As FEDERAL SAKURA proceeded upstream towards the Canadian Pacific Railway (CPR) bridges 7A and 7B, the vessel's bridge team noted that the signal lights on Bridge 7A were still red.  The pilot then attempted to contact the bridge operator, but there was no response.  The decision was made to stop the vessel under the Honoré-Mercier bridge, downstream from bridges 7A and 7B.  There was no headway, but the stern of the vessel brushed against the south pier of the Honoré-Mercier bridge.
After the operator of bridges 7A and 7B took ill, he was replaced by another bridge operator, who immediately activated the signal for train 89 to proceed on bridge 7A.  Subsequently, the bridge operator released bridge 7A's emergency stop push button and started raising the lift span to allow the FEDERAL SAKURA to continue its voyage.

The general cargo ship FAIZ departed a port in Yangoon for an Indian port with a full load of 900 mt of pulses on 27th May 2005. On 31st May 2005, when the vessel was about 150 nautical miles from Sand Head in the Bay of Bengal, a fire which apparently started in the Master's day room spread to other parts of the accommodation, and the vessel was abandoned by crew. Out of 15 crew members ten survived and four died: the Master, his wife, daughter and son. The Chief Officer jumped overboard without a life jacket in stormy seas and went mssing. The vessel drifted for 3 days, and the company arranged their own ship to tow the vessel, but without success. Ten crew were rescued by coast guard. A SAR was organized for the Chief Officer, but was abandoned on 6th June 2005. The vessel apparently sank on 5/6 June 2005. The coast guard official had previously boarded the vessel and found four human skulls in the Master's accommodation. The vessel sank due to a continuous ingress of water from stormy seas.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
The container vessel PUNJAB SENATOR left Singapore on 28 May 2005 at 05h13.  It was carrying a cargo of 31,604mt in altogether 1050 x 20' and 1094 x 40' containers and was on its way to Colombo, Sri Lanka.
On 30 May 2005 at 07h23, a container exploded.  It was located at the forward edge in hold no. 6 by the partition wall to the engine room.  The crew managed to bring the fire that finally extended over two containers holding standard, commercial, small, rechargeable batteries under control with massive use of CO2 and intensive cooling, and put the fire out.
No personal injuries were noted.  The damage to the cargo and the vessel was substantial.  No environmental damage was sustained.

On the morning of 29 March 2005, the wood-hulled fishing ship Justin M became trapped in ice-packed waters south of the Magdalen Islands while on a sea-hunting expedition. It was freed early the next morning by the Canadian Cast Guard Ship Amundsen but sank at 06:43 eastern standard time while being escorted to Cap aux Meules, Quebec. All 9 crew members   were rescued, and no injuries were reported.

During a sailing trip with SY Andrea among the Swedish skerry Islands, the boom of the main sail swung round as a result of a sudden gust in the afternoon of 28 May 2005, struck the skipper on the head, and flung him over board. 
Despite the rescue measures initiated immediately, the skipper could only be recovered dead three days later by divers.

On 25 May 2005 at 20.02 hours LT the  MV YUE SHAN's port bow collided with the starboard side of M.T Chrisopigi Lady. Both vessels were in stable condition after the collision. Assistance was given to the ship and rescue services were provided: the Singapore Port Authorithies requested pilot and tug assistance to MV Yue Shan. The owner arranged for temporary repairs to the vessel and looked for suitable tugs for the vessel to proceed to Majishan under tow by stern.

The MV  Yue Shan was later taken to Raffles Reserve Anchorage Singapore. Temporary repairs were completed as per classification, BV's requirement and vessel remained there until BV completed its inspection before issuance of certificates for vessel to proceed on her voyage to discharching port Majishan

On the 26 May 2005 the Yacht “ Megawat” sank following failure of the rudderstock. The craft was sailing from Dublin to Scotland in 20/30 knots of wind when a loud bang was heard, the steering failed and the craft began to take on water. The liferaft  was deployed to allow transfer to another yacht “Quite Correct” which was in the vicinity. The liferaft failed to inflate. The crew were successfully transferred using the inflatable tender belonging, to “Quite Correct”. The yacht “ Megawat sank in approximately 40 minutes.

At about 0540 on 24 May 2005, a fire started on board the Singapore registered general cargo ship Java Sea while it was berthed in Cairns. The fire started in the engine room adjacent to the oil-fired thermal fluid heater, at deck level, under the poop in way of the aft peak bulkhead.

Initial attempts by the ship’s crew to fight the fire using a fire hose were unsuccessful and the decision was taken to use the engine room Halon 1301 fixed fire extinguishing system. The release of the Halon 1301 proved ineffective, primarily because of the inability of the crew to close the dampers on the ventilation openings at the top of the funnel casing. 

The fire was finally extinguished by the Queensland Fire Service, using high expansion foam injected through a hole cut in the base of the funnel at poop deck level directly above the seat of the fire.

The engine room and accommodation were significantly damaged by the fire and the associated fire fighting activities, to such an extent that Java Sea had to be towed to Singapore for permanent repairs.

A fire broke out in the engine room of the container vessel LIBRA RIO GRANDE at about 10.20LT on 23/05/2005.  At that time the vessel was in the port of New Orleans.  The fire fighting started by the crew was later taken over by the local fire brigade.  It was possible to put out the fire by using CO2.  
The fire resulted in high property damage.  
There were no personal injuries or environmental damage.

Location: 4 miles S.E. of Berry Head, South Devon
SummaryOfEvents:
The small fishing vessel BOUNTY capsized and sank in Lyme Bay.  The vessel had her trawl caught on a seabed obstruction at the time.  The two crewmembers found themselves in the water, with lifebuoys, but were able to board the vessel's liferaft and were rescued about 5 hours later.
BOUNTY had departed Brixham earlier that morning for a day of bottom trawling.  The weather was initially fine, but deteriorated as the day progressed.  The snagging occurred during the first trawl while the vessel was stern to the wind and sea.  Engine power was used to try to free the vessel, but a wave broke over the stern and swamped the working deck.  The floodwater was trapped within the vessel's shelter and did not have time to clear through her freeing ports.  The vessel listed to port and then wallowed for about 20 seconds before capsizing.

On 18 May 2005, the Hong Kong registered general cargo ship ‘Hui Long’ was sailing from Sungei Pakning, Indonesia to India. The vessel was loaded with 11,245 tonnes of mixed general cargoes including 5,185 tonnes of fluorspar mineral in bulk. At around 15.35 hours ship’s time (UTC+5), whilst the vessel was 173 nautical miles from Sri Lanka, position at 5º 55.5’N 84º 20.7’E, the ship suddenly developed a list of 15 degrees to port. The list continued to worsen, and the Master abandoned the Vessel at 16.02 hours LT after the port weather deck had been immersed in water at a list of 40 degrees.  All 23 crew were rescued by the passing container vessel ‘P&O Nedlloyd Asia’. A salvage tug was called in the following day to try and rescue the vessel but without success, and the ship finally sank on 20th May 2005.

The exact cause of the sinking of ‘Hui Long’ could not be established. After investigating the probable causes of the accident, it is believed that the liquefaction of the fluorspar cargo inside the No.1 and No. 3 holds was the cause. The flow state of the fluorspar cargo might have developed a list to the vessel and caused it to capsize and sink.

ON MAY 18TH, 2005 WHILE THE TUGBOAT “TARENTUM” WAS ON ROUTE FROM NAPLES (ITALY) TO GARRUCHA (SPAIN) IT GROUNDED AT 12.15 HOURS LT IN THE VICINITY OF THE PORT OF SAINT TROPEZ.
INVESTIGATIONS REVEALED THAT THE ACCIDENT WAS CAUSED BY ADVERSE WEATHER CONDITIONS AND CARELESS MISTAKES BY THE CREW.
ONCE GROUNDED, THE CAPTAIN IMMEDIATELY INFORMED THE FRENCH COAST GUARD AND THE SHIPOWNER, AND THE NEXT DAY THE VESSEL WAS ASSISTED BY A SECOND TUG SENT FROM NAPLES. “TARENTUM” WAS THEN TOWED TO THE PORT OF NAPLES WHERE ARRIVED ON 23RD OF MAY 2005.

At 00h15 on 18th May 2005 the small trawler developed a list.  After investigation, the engineer discovered severe flooding in the engine room and a decision was made to evacuate the vessel.  Shortly after evacuation into the liferafts the fishing vessel rapidly sunk.  Distress signals were transmitted.  A nearby ship spotted the crewmembers and came to their rescue.

Just after 09.20 hours LT on 16 May 2005, the engineer cadet on the bulk carrier GOLDEN BELL fell through an open section of deck grating while working in the ships' engine room. He landed on the bottom deck plates, approximately seven metres below, suffering severe head and internal injuries. The ship was at anchor off the Western Australian port of Dampier. 

The cadet died as a result of his head injuries a short time after being evacuated by helicopter to the Nickol Bay Hospital in Karratha, about 20 km from Dampier.

During harbour maneouvres in Torshavn a technical defect of the reverse gear cropped up, and an astern maneouvre could not be carried out.

The ship continued sailing ahead and collided with three moored ships. One big fishing ship was hit on starboard bow below water line, and the foreship was flooded. Two smal fishing vessels had material damages. No persons were injured.

The skipper manouvred the ship having a blood alcohol level of 0,267 per cent.

The causal factor was a technical failure of the reverse gear.

On 16th May 2005 the Phoenix Beta, loaded with crude oil, was on her way to Antwerp in dense local fog when she collided with the M/V ISARGAS, which was empty and unclean of ethylene. Mt Phoenix Beta was passing M/V ISARGAS and about to pass an inland river vessel, loaded with MDO in narrow channel. Mt Phoenix Beta could not keep to the green side of the channel and collided with M/V ISARGAS.

During navigation toward anchorage at slow speed, a starboard turn was executed too late and too little in the sporadic surveyed water and the vessel hit a rock at high water and remained at ground. About 12 hours later, at next highwater the vessel was pulled off the rock. After a diver survey the vessel could continue its voyage.

On its way North in the Sound the master, alone on the bridge, fell asleep, and a planned alteration of the course was not executed. The vessel hit the small island Peberhom at a speed of 9.5 knots. The vessel was refloated by own means the following day at 1900 hours and following an inspection by divers could continue its route.

On 11th May 2005 the electrician on board the Marshall Islands registered PROBO PANDA died from a heart attack following a suspected electric shock while the ship was at anchor off Gladstone in Queensland.
The electrician died while working on one of the ship’s engine room light fittings. 
It is likely that the electrician was crouching on a deep frame at the lowest level of the engine room so he could reach the light fitting. He may have received an electric shock which knocked him off balance, causing him to fall between the deep frame and an adjacent pipe. The subsequent exertion of attempting to climb free probably induced a coronary artery occlusion. 

He had been missing for several hours and was only found after a search of the vessel was instigated by the master.

SOLASStatus: CJK LINHAI: Unknown/unspecified, SUN INVESTOR: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: GENERAL CARGO "CJK LINHAI" AND CHEMICAL/OIL CARRIER "SUN INVESTOR" WERE IN COLLISION.    CJK LINHAI HAS SOME BOW DAMAGE, WHILE SUN INVESTOR SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO PORT SIDE LIFEBOAT.

ON 10TH MAY 2005 THE CHEMICAL TANKER 'GORBY TENKO' WAS SAILING AT 37 30N, 023 58E AT 126 COURSE, WHEN ANOTHER VESSEL WAS SEEN APPROACHING FROM THE STARBOARD SIDE.  ITS SPEED AND POSITION WERE WATCHED CAREFULLY BUT BECAUSE OF THE SPEED AND CHANGING POSITION OF F/V PANAGI A COLLISION  OCCURRED AT 23.30 HOURS LT. THE GORBY TENKO'S RUDDER WAS TAKEN TO FULL PORT IN AN ATTEMPT TO AVOID THE COLLISION, BUT CONTACT WAS MADE AT AFT BOARD STARBOARD SIDE.

InitialEvent: labour accident with hatch cover crane
SummaryOfEvents: At 14.00 hours LT on 22nd June 2005 a fire broke out in the engine room of side trawler JOHANNES during fishing. The fire detector had not sounded, but poor fire fighting methods were used as well: part of the ventilation system was not closed, no boundary cooling applied, activation of Quick Closing Valve initially "forgotten". The crew thought they had activated the Halon system, but they had not, nor were portable fire fighting appliances used. The crew were saved by surrounding vessels.

WHILE VESSEL ENROUTE TO ONEBROGUGSKIY, UKRAIN FOR DISCHARGING HER CARGO, AT 13.20LT, IN POSITION LOT 37°29/LONG 26.22,3 ON 10 MAY 2005, THE VESSEL SHAKED FOR OR WHILE WITH ANY UNUSUAL VIBRATION.  MEANTIME CREW ALERTED TAKING ALL EMERGENCY POSITIONS.  THE SPEED FOR THE TIME OF THE COLLISION WAS 13.5 KNOTS.  IN FEW MINUTES WATER EXPANDED OUT OF THE WENT PIPES OF BOTH FOREPEAK TANKS AND DOUBLE BOTTOM TANK-1 STBD. THE MASTER INSTRUCTED IMMEDIATELY SOME OFFICERS AND CREW TO CHECK HULL OF THE VESSEL, AS FOR AS SEEN FLOODING OF FOREPEAK TANK UP TO THE SEA LEVEL AND DOUBLE BOTTOM TANK 1STBD FULLY HAS HAPPENED.

On 7th May 2005 a caterer who worked for the owner of the tug boat OTTON  was visiting a client on another  vessel which was moored at the same dock. When passing by the tug he decided to get inside to have a look,  as it had been without a crew for a period of about 5 years.  The tug was moored there waiting for the owner to decide on the repairs needed, and to be reclassed.  
Upon boarding the vessel from the dock, he slipped and hit his head, which resulted in his untimely death.  As no crew were on board the tug, there was no entrance thereto and the distance between the dock and the rail was quite considerable.

On 5th May 2005 at 23.43 hours LT knocking noises were heard from the fore part of the main engine of the oil tanker WALNUT EXPRESS, and  the engine was stopped immediately. On inspecting the crank case, white metal particles were noted which had accumulated with pieces of bearing metal under the number one main journal. A smaller quantity of white metal  particles were noted under the number two main journal. 
The bearings of number one and two were then opened and the following was noted:
 - the top and lower sectio nof the main bearing shells were damaged and corresponding damages to the journal pin, indicating hard contact marks. 
 - the top and bottom of the number two journal shell were damaged.

On May 5th 2006 at 15:40 hours LT the vessel was at position 07º15.5 N , and 079º56.3 West  when it was found that the main engine turbo charger was blocked. Flanges were fitted to the turbo charger casing  in order for the ship to be able to continue its journey without turbo charger operation.

On May 2005, a fatal sailing accident occurred on board the sailing yacht Sinfonie Sylt in the Flensburger Förde. The ship with three experienced yacht persons familiar with the boat on board had left her anchorage off the Danish harbour of Höruphav towards 08:30 a.m. and was sailing on a general course of about 140° with wind from the stern on her way to Kiel. At the time of the accident the helmsman and yachtwoman were staying on deck. According to her observations, shortly after the helmsman had switched on the automatic pilot and had left the port side control   stand going to the cockpit, the yacht fell off to the lee side at 09:05 a.m. with a subsequent accidental gybe. On this occasion the helmsman was hit by the main sheet and thrown against the inner edge of the cockpit. On this occasion he suffered severe injuries. 
The skipper on the yacht, who was made aware of the situation by the joint-sailor’s cry for help, rushed on deck and instructed the joint-sailor to furl the head sail, in order to stabilise the boat and to regain control over it. After he had again gone below deck for a short while, in order to make an emergency call via VHF, he then tried to reanimate the unconscious helmsman until the rescue team would arrive on the scene. Towards 09:20 a.m., a ship of the Federal Police arrived at the scene of the accident. Her crew took the seriously injured victim on board and continued the resuscitation efforts until the rescue ship  Jens Füerschipp, which the MRCC  Bremen had ordered to the scene  of the accident, arrived on the scene. A doctor, who had offered the rescue team of DGzRS his assistance in the port of Gelting Mole and then had accompanied them to the scene of the accident, stated the helmsman’s death at 10:01 a.m.

Location: Off South of Uotsuri Island, Okinawa Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
On 4th May 2005 the bulk carrier THIA CHRYSSOULA (registered Cyprus, 31643 gt, built 1990), with 31 crew members on board: (Greek: 4, Ukrainian: 4, Indian: 23), ran aground at 23.47 hours LT on the shallows off South of Uotsuri Island, Okinawa Prefecture, Japan.
As a result, she sustained scratching, cracking and hole damage to her shell plate. However, she was refloated by tug and proceeded to Pohang Port.

At about 15: 00 hours on 01 May 2005 the 69-years old skipper of SY INA 2 was lost over board off Wustrow on a voyage from Warnemunde to Rerik. The sea was absolutely calm and the co-sailor was just engaged in taking down the main sail under engine power, when his attention was drawn to the accident by a call. He immediately rushed aft and saw the skipper holding on to the railing outboard on a level with the cockpit on the port side with one hand. When the co-sailor did not succeed in holding the skipper by the railing, the skipper drifted away from the boat. After a “person over board” manoeuvre the co-sailor succeeded in bringing the man who had fallen over board aft at the boat ladder. At this time the accident victim was already lifeless and could no longer support the rescue attempts. In this condition it was not possible to put the accident victim on board over the boat’s ladder from the stern. That is why he was provisionally secured to the boat ladder with a boat hook and a line. The co-sailor then sent out an emergency call via VHF radio telephone that was heard by several radio stations. After an unsuccessful attempt to recovery, the accident victim drifted off again and was finally recovered at 15:47 hours by the inflatable boat of Warnow and brought on board the Warnow. The emergency physician who had arrived in the meantime with the SAR helicopter continued the resuscitation measures that had already been started and ascertained the death of the accident victim at 16:20 hours

The chemical tanker MT Metanol completed its sea passage from Yuzhnyy, Ukraine to Lavera, France where it was due to discharge its cargo of methyl alcohol.  The vessel arrived at Lavera roads on 29 April 2005 and berthed alongside at Quay H.

At 0040 on 30 April 2005 the discharge arms were connected to ship’s manifold.  Although a discussion had taken place between the chief officer and the oil terminal personnel regarding the use of a nitrogen blanket in the cargo tanks during the discharge operations, the port personnel seemed not to require such precautions.  By 0055, the MT Metanol started discharging its cargo.  This was initially started by deep-well pumps no. 11 and 12.

At 0110 an explosion occurred in cargo tank no. 12.  The tank lid was blown away and a fire subsequently started and spread from cargo tank no.12 to the upper deck. The ship’s alarm was sounded and the fire team assembled.

The fire in the cargo tank was extinguished by 0115 utilising both portable fire extinguishers and a fire hose.  At 0130 the harbour master and a shore-based fire fighting team boarded the vessel.

As a result of the explosion, the tank lid of cargo tank no.12 was blown off and the access trunk to cargo tank no.12 was also distorted.
LOST OF STEERING DUE TO BAD WEATHER.

Location: Santa Cruz de Tenerife, Canary Islands
SummaryOfEvents: At about 19h30 on 27/04/2005 a fatal work accident occurred on board the German container vessel WERDER BREMEN.  During work on deck in the port of Santa Cruz de Tenerife, a crew member fell from a height of approximately 7m from the hatch cover onto the pier.  The seaman had been in a lashing passage on hatch 2.  Here the hatch cover extends up to the outer side of the vessel.  There were no structural measures to prevent falling overboard at this place.  The seaman was not wearing any personal fall protection equipment.
Consequences1: Ship remains fit to proceed,Loss of life

SummaryOfEvents: Dans la nuit du 26 au 27 avril 2005, le Massabielle est en pêche à la coauille Saint-Jacque ) l'ouest de Guernesey; lors des opérations de virage des engins et de l'embarquement d'une drague, un des matelots perd l'équilibre et tombe à la mer

The Motor fishing Vessel Pod Sant Yann departed from Union Hall, Co. Cork on the morning of 25 April 2005 at approximately 03:00 UST to undertake a fishing trip which began at fishing ground 12 miles South of Baltimore. 

Fishing continued throughout that day until late in the night. The ship moved to different areas as it trawled.

On the morning of 26 April 2005 a fire occurred in the main engine room, which rapidly went out of control. The ship was abandoned and the crew were rescued by another fishing vessel. 
The ship burned until eventually sinking on the evening of 26 April 2005.

There were no injuries, loss of life or pollution caused by this incident.
MISSING PERSON
COLLISION BETWEEN TWO VESSELS

At about 08.40 hours LT on 21 April 2005, a crewman on board the bulk carrier Hui Shun Hai suffered severe burns after pressurised hydraulic oil ignited while he was working on a deck hydraulic pipe. Immediately following the blast, he ran to the ship's side and jumped into the sea.

He was recovered from the water and evacuated by helicopter to the Western Australian town of Carnarvon. As a result of the explosion, he suffered burns to about 40 per cent of his body. The severity of his injuries resulted in his later transfer to the Royal Perth Hospital.
Sinking
Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Loss of life

SummaryOfEvents:
The MT SAETTA loaded 54,342.36 mt of fuel oil at Mamonal, Colombia on 19 April 2005 and in the afternoon proceeded to the inner anchorage. The vessel dropped anchor since she was scheduled to transit the Cartagena Ocean Transit Channel on the next day between 0600 and 1100.

On 20 April 2005 at 0600, two local pilots boarded the vessel and together with the master the outgoing passage plan was discussed.

The anchor was heaved up and at 0630 the passage commenced. At the time, the vessel’s draught was 11.8 m even keel.

The third officer, a helmsman, the chief engineer and the two local pilots accompanied the Master on the bridge at the time. Three tugs, one on each side forward and one on the centre line aft were assisting the vessel.

During transiting the channel, when the vessel was turning to starboard to enter into the Bocachia Channel, the vessel rolled twice abruptly.

The master drew the attention of the pilots and at the same time the chief mate reported sounds of escaping air from the No.1 port ballast tank vents and that oil was visible in the water on the port side of the vessel.

The vessel started to list to port.

The master requested the senior pilot to take the vessel to the safe outer anchorage. In order to reduce the hydrostatic head of the cargo and minimise the pollution, the master instructed the chief mate to start transferring by gravity the cargo in the No.1 cargo tank to the No. 4 cargo tank, which was empty at the time, 

No.1 starboard ballast tank was ballasted to bring the vessel upright.

At 0822, the vessel dropped anchor at the outer anchorage and a boom was deployed around the vessel to contain any further oil leakages from the vessel.

Inspections to verify the extent of the damages sustained were initiated.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
On 19th April 2005 at 23.30 hours LT, the vessel was fishing for blue whiting between Norway and the Faroe Isles when a leak occurred in the engine room. The skipper started a bilge pump as routine procedure, but failed to investigate the leak. 10 to 15 minutes later the water level in the engine room had increased. Another electric powered bilge pump was started, but it is uncertain whether it was working properly. Attempts were then made to start a diesel powered emergency pump, but it could not be activated because of poor maintanance and crew members' lack of skill.
The skipper asked for assistance from another Danish fishing vessel which was operating 4 to 5 nm away, whilst the crewmembers disembarked and entered a life raft. No distress signals were transmitted because they felt safe in the knowledge that another ship was in the vicinity.
After some 30 to 45 minutes in the life raft the crewmembers were rescued by the other ship. Some 1½ hours later GRACELAND foundered.

On 16th April 2005 the NORWEGIAN DAWN was en route from the Bahamas to New York. As a result of stormy weather the windows of the two forward facing cabins on Decks 9 and 10 were broken by the force of a wave.
Four passengers suffered minor injuries.
GROUNDED WHILE ATTEMPTING TO ANCHOR OFF NASSAU IN STRONG NORTHERLY WINDS AT ABOUT 1600, APRIL 15.  LOCAL TUGS SUCCEEDED IN PULLING IT FREE FROM THE SHORELINE AND THE VESSEL IS NOW SAFELY AFLOAT.

At 05.35 hours LT on 15 April 2005, the Greek registered bulk carrier Spartia collided with the Australian rock lobster fishing vessel Hannah Lee, 17 nautical miles off Cape Bouvard, in position 32 43.8'S, 115 16.9'E, on Western Australia's south-west coast. Spartia was in ballast and making for the port of Bunbury to load alumina. Hannah Lee had departed the small port of Mandurah at 03.45 hours to work its rock lobster pots located approximately 37 nautical miles south-west of the port.

Hannah Lee's skipper failed to observe Spartia in the time leading up to the collision as he was preoccupied with keeping his vessel on course. The bridge team on Spartia had identified the fishing vessel about 20 minutes prior to the collision. They had assessed that a risk of collision existed but, as Hannah Lee was on their port side, they maintained the vessel's course and speed, in accordance with the international collision regulations. When it became obvious to the bridge team that Hannah Lee was not going to give way, the master ordered avoiding action, consisting of a change in course and turn to starboard.

This action was ineffective in preventing the collision and Hannah Lee impacted Spartia's port side, in way of number six hold a short time later. No one was injured in the collision and no pollution resulted.

After the collision, Spartia continued its voyage to Bunbury, where it anchored at 09.00 hours LT. Hannah Lee made for the port of Fremantle where it berthed at a repair yard at about 09.10 hours LT.

Location: Approaches to Alfred Lock, Birkenhead docks, River Mersey
SummaryOfEvents:
At about 0210 on 13 April 2005, the UK registered tug THORNGARTH was assisting the Liberian registered chemical tanker STOLT ASPIRATION and acting as bow tug.  The two vessels collided when THORNGARTH was attempting to recover her position ahead of STOLT ASPIRATION.
As a consequence of the impact, THORNGARTH was holed below the waterline ans sustained significant structural damage.  The tug's engineer also suffered a broken arm.  STOLT ASPIRATION suffered only minor damage to its bow.  There were no other injuries or pollution.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Serious injuries

Location: 22 14.9N 114 06.6E MIDSTREAM NORTH LAMMA ANCHORAGE HONG KONG
SummaryOfEvents:
On 11 April 2005, the MV Philippine Star was at Hong Kong Midstream North Lamma Anchorage.

Several crew members were replacing various steel plates on the vessel’s deck.

At 1815, a fitter who was working on deck, sustained extensive burns when his gas cutting equipment rubber hose caught fire.

The Marine Department Accident Investigation Section, Hong Kong, was advised and a MEDEVAC was requested.

The injured fitter was transferred by helicopter to Queen Mary Hospital, Hong Kong, where he succumbed to his injuries two days later.
During vessel's mooring tightening procedures Chief Officer Ranulfo Cagulada experienced a left leg injury when one of the mooring lines hit him.
On 6th April 2005 the fishing trawler MAARTEN JACOB was in the North Sea. When a net was pulled on board a bomb was discovered which exploded at 15.00 hours LT. Three crew members died as a result.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: Northwest of the coast of Izu-Oshima Island, Japanese Pacific coast island
SummaryOfEvents: Capsized by waves about 4 metres.

Location: PORT OF PALMA DE MALLORACA, BAELLIARIC ISLANDS
SummaryOfEvents:
The MV Panagia I completed its sea passage from San Lorentzo, Argentina to the Balearic Islands and intended to berth at the port of Palma de Mallorca to discharge 26940mt of maize.  The vessel’s draft at the time was of 9.95m on an even keel.

The vessel had arrived at the pilot boarding station by 1445 on 03 April 2005 and the pilot immediately boarded the vessel.  Two tugs made fast with the Panagia I, one forward and one aft.  Berthing manoeuvres then began at 1500.

At 1532, the master requested the pilot to instruct the aft tug to assist in stopping the vessel’s heading and the forward tug to pull to portside so as to assist in turning the vessel.  At 1534, the aft towline parted.  The Panagia I continued making way towards the berth at an angle of 45º.  At 1535 the vessel’s bulbous bow made contact with underwater rocks at a distance of 3m from the berth.  As a result, the vessel sustained damage in the side shell plating in way of the bulbous bow.  At 1630, the crew noticed ingress of water inside the forepeak tank.  Deballasting of the forepeak commenced at 1640.

The vessel was eventually berthed and cargo discharge operations commenced.  As a temporary repair, plastic steel was applied to the crack on the outside shell plating to seal off the crack and a steel doubler plate was welded in place from the inside.

The MV Athinoula berthed at the port of Diliskelsi, Turkey on 30 March 2005 at 2329, to load a cargo of steel products.  A stowage plan to the stevedores.  Loading operations commenced at 1115 the following day.  The ship’s cranes, operated by the stevedores, were used to load the cargo.During the loading operations on 02 April 2005, a sling used to transfer the cargo from ashore to the ship failed.  The steel billet, weighing approximately 16 tonnes,  fell into cargo hold no. 5 and penetrated the tank top and the bottom shell plating.  Water ingress to the double bottom and cargo hold no. 5 was reported.  The crew immediately began de-ballasting the double bottom tank and cargo hold no. 5.  Temporary repairs were then carried out.

Location: Wahda Bay, Lifou, Isles Loyauté, New Caledonia
SummaryOfEvents:
After experiencing a propulsion failure at around 15h30 on 1st April 2005, TEHORO III, a former fishing vessel recently converted into a cargo vessel, was unable to restart its engines and asked for the assistance of the oil tanker KONEMU.
Due to south-east winds, the ship drifted dangerously towards a nearby reef and despite the attempts from KONEMU to assist, TEHORO III failed to anchor and grounded.  A few minutes later, KONEMU also grounded about 200m away on the Lifou coastal reef.

Location: Saronic Gulf, approx. 35 kms south of Athens
SummaryOfEvents: On 31st March 2005 the vehicle-carrier ANIARA, en route from Alexandria to Piraeus, was about 20 nautical miles from its destination when a fire broke out in the engine room, at around midday. The crew were unable to extinguish the fire, and two patrol boats and a salvage craft proceeded to the area, along with a naval vessel. Fire-fighting vessels were placed on standby, and at the Master's request Search & Rescue helicopters rescued the 24 crew members, none of whom were injured. Salvors later succeeded in attaching a line to the vessel, which was towed to a sheltered location where the fire was totally extinguished. Eventually the ship underwent repairs at the Hellenic Shipyards in Skaramanga (Greece).

Le 31 mai 2005, la vedette palangrier-trémailleur SÉBASTIEN II fait route au Sud Sud/Est à la vitesse de 10 noeuds vers le port de Dunkerque après avoir posé ses filets au large du banc du Ruytingen.
Le même jour, le chalutier KERBULIC est en pêche au chalut de fond sur le banc
du Dyck central situé au large de Dunkerque. Il suit un cap au 250° à la vitesse moyenne de 3 noeuds.
Vers 09 heures 40 TU pour le Patron du SÉBASTIEN II, vers 09 heures 45 TU pour le Patron du KERBULIC, les deux navires entrent en collision malgré l’ultime manœuvre du Kerbulic pour éviter l’abordage (annexe C : cartographie et relevés du CROSS.Gris-Nez).
Sur le SÉBASTIEN II, le point d’impact se situe au niveau de l’étrave. Sur le KERBULIC, le point d’impact se situe à tribord, au dessus de la flottaison, au niveau de la marque Boulogne-Etaples inscrite sur la coque.
Aucune assistance n’est demandée de la part des deux navires. Le SÉBASTIEN II fait route vers Dunkerque pour débarquer les blessés. Le KERBULIC fait route vers Boulogne-Sur-Mer, assisté du canot de sauvetage NOTRE DAME DU RISBAN de Calais, pour que les dégâts soient constatés et obtenir l’aval des autorités maritimes pour repartir en pêche.
On 29th March 2005 the Officer on duty fell asleep on board the fishing vessel  ANNIE B  Z.28, and the ship ran into the Oosterscheldedam. After the collision the ship sank. There were no casualties

Le vendredi 27 mai 2005, le fileyeur GAELLE-NOLWENN, immatriculé à Morlaix sous le numéro 732493, quitte le port de Mogueriec à 19h30 afin d’aller mouiller des filets sur ses zones de pêche situées à une vingtaine de milles.
Quelques heures plus tard, alors que le patron se prépare à mettre les filets à l’eau, le navire s’enfonce par l’arrière puis chavire brusquement. Les quatre hommes d’équipage, accrochés à la coque retournée, parviennent à prendre place dans un des radeaux de sauvetage.
Ils sont recueillis sains et saufs par le porte-conteneurs danois ADRIAN MAERSK
le 28 mai vers 05h00, puis hélitreuillés sur l’hôpital de Brest.

1.- El día 27 de Marzo de 2005 el TVH “Chinook”  de bandera chilena, varó en la costa de Caleta Potter en el territorio Antártico, en circunstancias que se encontraba fondeada a la  gira afectada por vientos del  W/NW, fuerza 7 a 8.  

2.- La nave se encontraba fondeada en Caleta Potter debido a que durante ese mismo día, había sido inspeccionada por la Autoridad Marítima de Bahía Fildes, por haberse detectado durante la navegación a Punta Arenas, el día 21 de Marzo, una fisura en el Bow thruster, situación que sumada al mal tiempo imperante en la zona, obligó a la nave a regresar al punto de zarpe.  
 
3.- Aproximadamente a las 19:45 horas el Segundo Piloto sube al Puente para  verificar la posición de la nave antes de retirarse a descansar, lo que hizo mediante el sistema GPS, percatándose en ese momento que el buque estaba  garreando, lo cual informó de inmediato al Capitán quien también se encontraba en el Puente.

4.- Se inició el virado de la cadena y se empleó la máquina para ayudar a la maniobra, sin embargo estas acciones no impidieron que la nave fuera abatida hacia la costa del lado sur de la bahía y quedara apoyada sobre el hielo con una escora de 5° a estribor.  Posteriormente se continuó maniobrando con la máquina para tratar de liberarse de los hielos, hasta cerca de las 23:00 horas, momento en que se suspendió la maniobra hasta el día siguiente.

5.- A las 07:10 horas del día 28 de Marzo de 2005 y luego de haber intentado infructuosamente sacar la nave de su posición de varada, el Capitán suspende dichas maniobras e informa lo sucedido a la Capitanía de Puerto de Bahía Fildes.

6.- Finalmente la nave fue desvarada a las 18:05 horas con el apoyo del Rompehielos “ALMIRANTE VIEL” de la Armada de Chile, quedando  fondeada a la gira con seis paños de cadena, dándose por finalizada la maniobra de desvarada.

7.- Con motivo de este siniestro, la nave no derramó hidrocarburos, sufriendo diversas averías en su casco, debiendo posteriormente ser remolcada por otra nave hasta Punta Arenas.

8.-  La varada de la TVH “Chinook”, el 27 de Marzo de 2005, en Caleta Potter, Antártica chilena, se debió a errores humanos cometidos por el  Oficial de Guardia y por el Capitán respectivamente, mientras estuvieron a cargo del control del buque en el puente de mando, debido principalmente a falta de previsión y control de la posición del fondeo de la nave, en los instantes previos a la varada.

At 11.50 hours LT on 24 March 2005, a fire broke out in the engine room of the Hong Kong registered bulk carrier "Fleet Trader 1", when en route from Tenerife to Lagos. The fire spread into part of the accommodation around the engine room areas resulting in the death of the Third Engineer. The incident caused substantial damage to the engine room and the accommodation space.

The investigation revealed that the fire was caused by overflowing fuel oil from the boiler fuel oil tank which came into contact with the main engine hot exhaust gas manifold and ignited. 

Contributing to the cause of the fire was that the filling valve for the boiler fuel oil tank was wrongly opened by the Junior Engineer. This mistake was unfortunately compounded by two major defects on the boiler fuel oil tank system. Firstly, the boiler F.O. return line to the boiler fuel oil tank had been modified leaving behind an opening on the top of the boiler fuel oil tank. Secondly, the overflow line from the boiler fuel oil tank was blocked with rusty debris. As a result, excess fuel oil overflowed from the opening at the top of the tank and came into contact with the hot exhaust trunk.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

On 22nd March 2005 a Cyprus flagged bulk carrier of 15,944 GT loaded with 23,200 tonnes of coal was en route northbound through Route T. After passing the Great belt, a cooling water pipe needed to be repaired. The master deviated from the planned route in Route T and allowed the ship to drift in the area north of Røsnes while the repair work was carried out.
After having drifted for 45 minutes, the navigation was resumed. At this moment they intended to continue by the planned route in Route T quite close to the ground Leveret. However, because they were unaware of their exact position and due to currents the ship was grounded at 12.02 hours LT. There was no personal injury.

The vessel grounded when leaving Oxelösund, Sweden.
There was no pilot on board and the vessel proceeded on the wrong side of a sea mark.
Some of the sea marks were not visible due to ice conditions.

Le 20 mars 2005, le caboteur MAGNOLIA se trouve dans le dispositif de séparation de trafic, voie descendante, entre Douvres et la bouée Greenwich ; il suit un cap au 256° et sa vitesse est de 9 noeuds.
L’officier de quart ne voit pas de navire et ne repère pas au radar de trace ou d’écho d’un navire sur son côté avant tribord.
Le 20 mars 2005, le chalutier JENNIVIC est en pêche aux abords de la partie Ouest de la voie descendante du dispositif de séparation de trafic du Pas-de-Calais.
Il suit à ce moment un cap au 200° et sa vitesse est de 2,8 à 3 noeuds sur le fond. Le matelot de veille voit un navire arriver sur son arrière bâbord.
A 05 heures 13 (heure française) pour le chalutier JENNIVIC et à 04 heures 20 (UTC) pour le caboteur MAGNOLIA, les deux navires entrent en collision sans qu’aucun des deux n’ait tenté la moindre manoeuvre. Sur le MAGNOLIA, le point d’impact se situe à tribord au milieu du navire.
Sur le JENNIVIC, le point d’impact se situe à bâbord au niveau de la partie arrière du gaillard.
Aucune assistance ni de la part du chalutier JENNIVIC ni du caboteur MAGNOLIA n’est demandée.
Le caboteur MAGNOLIA continue sa route.
Le chalutier JENNIVIC, n’ayant pas d’avarie majeure, continue sa pêche.

On 17th March 2005 the general cargo ship LIFANA was approaching the port of Rotterdam in dense fog when she collided with the m/v OPDR PORTO at 22.15 hours LT. The OPDR Porto had not seen m/v Lifana, due to poor radar performance and did not take action to prevent a collision. The m/v Lifana had seen mv OPDR  Porto on radar but continued on her voyage. Neither vessel reduced speed. Just before the collision Port Control warned both vessels, which only then took measures to prevent a collision. Only material damage was caused.

The fishing vessel was hit in starboard side by the cargo vessel. The sole fisherman on board the fishing vessel was working on the deck at the time of the collision and the master on the cargo vessel did not observe the fishing vessel neither by radar nor visually. The fisherman fell overboard. The crew on the cargo vessel lowered the mand- overboard- boat and the fisherman, who was very perised with cold, was picked up 20 minutes after. The fishing was lost.

Location: Marseille harbour, 2nm S. of Cap Couronne
SummaryOfEvents:
On 8 March 2005 at about 19h30 local time, the Algerian registered passenger/ro-ro cargo vessel TLEMCEN collided with the French registered oil tanker FS LOUISE at approximately 2 nautical miles South of Cap Couronne.
Both ships suffered quite considerable structural damages. However the accident did not result in any pollution and there were no injuries.
The investigation carried out by France concludes that the collision was due to the failure to comply with the COLREGs.

SOLASStatus: RICKMERS GENOA: Unknown/unspecified, SUN CROSS: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
At 1450 on 7 March 2005, the Korean registered general cargo ship SUN CROSS was on passage from the port of Lansham in China to the port of Yawata in Japan with a crew of 15 after loading 4,877 tons of pig iron.
At 0300 the next morning, the Second Mate of the SUN CROSS contacted the Marshall Islands registered general cargo ship RICKMERS GENOA, which had left the port of Shanghai for the port of Qingdao in China with 12,927.7 tons of cargo. On VHF radio he asked the RICKMERS GENOA to maintain her course and speed.  At the time, the SUN CROSS noticed on radar that the RICKMERS GENOA was approaching from 1.34 miles at one o'clock position on her starboard forward.
At 0302 when the two ships were only 690m apart, the OOW of the SUN CROSS observed the RICKMERS GENOA with the naked eye and put the helm to hard-a-starboard to avoid the imminent collision.  Almost at the same time, the RICKMERS GENOA turned to portside.
At 0303, as the heading of the SUN CROSS pointed to 195degreesT, the portside shell plating in the lower bridge of the SUN CROSS collided with the starboard bow of the RICKMERS GENOA with an intersection angle of 88 degrees.  The SUN CROSS sank right after the collision, leaving thirteen crew members dead or missing and two wounded.
The RICKMERS GENOA suffered severe damages in F'cle, Nos 1 & 2 cargo holds due to the explosion of cargoes caused by the collision, leaving the Chief Mate missing.
Weather conditions : the visibility was limited within 700m with the northwesterly wind at 8-10m/s and a wave height of about 1.5-2m.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Loss of life

SummaryOfEvents:
The MV Gerda Vesta departed from the port of Borusan Lojistik, Gemlik, Turkey on 06 March 2005 bound for Elevsis, Greece laden with a cargo of steel coils.  The vessel’s draft on departure was 4.60m forward and 5.15m aft.

The vessel passed the Sea of Marmara and the Canakkale Strait.  For the passage through the Dardanelles the vessel took a pilot onboard.  The pilot then disembarking at 2135 on 07 March 2005 after successfully navigating through the strait.

The vessel made several course alterations during the evening and at 2155 the vessel was approaching Bozcaada Island.  Although vessels normally passed to the West of Bozcaada Island, due to the weather conditions at the time, the master decided to pass to the East of the Island.  The sea and wind conditions at the time were southwesterly force 5.

At 2350 the master ordered an alteration in course from 200º to 177º, however, at 0005 on 08 March 2005, the vessel ran aground over rocks in way of Bozcaada Island.  The vessel sustained damage to its forepeak tank and several double bottom tanks, taking on a list to starboard.  After carrying out temporary repairs on site, the vessel proceeded back to Gemlik, Turkey to discharge its cargo before proceeding to a shipyard for permanent repairs.

AT SEA, ON MONDAY 7TH OF MARCH 2005 AT 19.37 HRS, THE MAIN ENGINE GAVE ALARM AND STOPPED WITH BLACK OUT AS A RESULT. AT 19.50 THE CHIEF ENGINEER STARTED THE INVESTIGATION FOR WHAT HAPPENED; HE OPENED CRANKCASE COVERS AND THE ROKER ARM COVERS AND SAW SOME COOLING WATER FLOATING BETWEEN THE PISTONS. AT SEA ON 9TH AT 10.30 HRS, AT NORTH OF SALINA ISLAND, THE ITALIAN COAST GUARD PROCEEDED TO THE VESSEL "BBC SCOTLAND" FOR NECESSARY SUPPORT. ON 10TH OF MARCH AT 00.45 HRS THE TUG BOAT "MILAE" ARRIVED NEAR THE SHIP AND TOWED "BBC SCOTLAND" TO MESSINA. AT 07.53 HRS THE CONVOY PASSED THE ENTRANCE OF MESSINA PORT

On 07 March 2005, the MV Oneida was sailing in ballast, with a pilot on board, up the River Parana, Guazu, bound for the port of Rosario.

At 1820, the master, who had been on the bridge for some hours, went down to the mess for dinner and afterwards retired to his cabin.

The chief mate was the officer in charge of the navigational watch. A helmsman and one of the Parana River pilots were also on the bridge. The other pilot was resting at the time in his cabin.

The chief mate and the pilot were standing on the starboard side of the bridge talking to each other. The vessel was proceeding at a speed of 11.3 knots.

At 1852, the vessel was felt to slow down and started to vibrate. The chief mate and the pilot ran to the port side of the bridge, from where they could see a small vessel being pushed along by the MV Oneida. Some time later, the small vessel capsized.

The chief mate went to the engine telegraph and stopped the main engine.

The master ran up to the bridge thinking that the vessel had grounded. When he arrived on the bridge he found the pilot and the chief mate panicking.

Looking over the port wing, he was able to see the small capsized ship abeam of his vessel. The master immediately rang the general alarm and put the main engine on astern.

Some time later, the vessel anchored and the port lifeboat was lowered to assist in the rescue operation of the crew of the capsized vessel.

The small vessel was the Panama registered sand carrier MV Matias F. Erausquin, which was picking up sand at position Km 227.

The MV Matias F. Erausquin sank about three hours later. Another vessel and local fishermen rescued five of the nine crew members. 

Four of the crew remained missing.

SummaryOfEvents:
On 04 March 2005, the MV ALGARVE was at the port of Coronel, Chile, loading a cargo of lumber and wood pulp.

The stevedores were loading lumber in holds No.4 and No.7 and wood pulp in hold No.6. Other stevedores were chocking the cargo in hold No.1.

The third officer had taken over the cargo watch at 0600 and was supervising the cargo operations, assisted by some of the crew members.

At 0730 the stevedores on the night shift left the vessel.

At this time the master went on deck to inspect the vessel. All was found in order and safe for cargo operations. The weather was good, calm and sunny.

At 0805 the day shift stevedores arrived on board and cargo operations were resumed.

At 0900, the stevedore’s foreman informed the third officer, who was near hold No.1 supervising the chocking of cargo in that hold, that an accident had happened in No.6 hold.

The fire broke out in the engine room of the 170-metre Fjord Champion late on Friday 4 March 2005. Although the ship was not transporting oil, it still had 800 tons of fuel on board for its own consumption.

The ship's 28 crew, were evacuated by helicopter on Friday night and Saturday morning.

It was not clear what started the fire on the ship, which was towed further out to sea on Saturday to help firefighters and to protect the coastline and neighbouring islands in case of an oil spill.

The KAREN DANIELSEN was a Bahamas registered general cargo ship of 3120 gross tonnes, which was built in 1985 and collided with the Great Belt West Bridge shortly after departure from the port of Svendborg in Denmark.

KAREN DANIELSEN departed from Svendborg with a pilot on board on 3 March 2005 at 1630 hours bound for Finland, in ballast, with a draft of 4.6 m.

At 1706 hours the pilot informed VTS Great Belt that the vessel was sailing towards Thurø Rev bound for Finland and would pass around Vresen (north of Langeland). After this, it would head south through the Great Belt.

At 1715 hours the pilot left the ship when it was off Thurø. At this time the master and the 2nd officer were on the bridge. The 2nd officer was at the helm.

At 1720 hours the steering was changed to auto pilot. The course was 026° from 1730 hours. 

At 1800 hours the 2nd officer’s duty ended, and he left the bridge at approximately 1805 hours.

At approximately 1815 hours the chief officer came to the bridge and shortly after, the master left to eat. After this, the chief officer was alone on the bridge.

At 1820 hours when KAREN DANIELSEN was off Stokkebaek Flak, the course was altered to 005°. The speed was 11.5 knots. It was twilight and the weather was clear.

At approximately 1857 hours the ship was due to alter to an easterly course to pass north of Langeland according to the passage planning inserted in the GPS. However, the ship continued on a course of 005°.

At approximately 1907 hours KAREN DANIELSEN collided with the western section of the Great Belt Bridge (West Bridge) approximately 800 m from Fyn. The foremast hit the bridge first and was bent astern. Then the forward crane hit and collapsed onto the hatch. After that, the aft crane hit and fell into the water. Finally, the superstructure hit the bridge and the entire wheelhouse was torn off, together with the funnel. 

At 1912 hours the ship transmitted a Mayday distress signal, and the VTS Centre realised that something was wrong.

The VTS Centre called the police, Storebælt A/S (The Great Belt Link) and DSB (Danish Rail), and the traffic over The Great Belt Bridge was stopped. Furthermore, the VTS Centre ordered the guard vessel VTS 3 from Slipshavn to sail towards the bridge.

VTS 3 and the vessel Y 376 took the crew from KAREN DANIELSEN on board and they were brought to Sliphavn. The master was injured severely in the collision and another crewmember was injured during the rescue. The chief officer was missing and a search was organised, but he was not found.

At approximately 0100 hours after the damage to the bridge had been examined, a tug pulled KAREN DANIELSEN clear and the ship was towed to Lindholm Harbour. 

At approximately 0130 hours 4 March, the Great Belt Bridge was reopened for road and rail traffic.

On 4 March at 1240 hours, the chief officer was found dead in the wreckage of the wheelhouse on board the KAREN DANIELSEN. At the post-mortem examination, the result of the alcohol test proved to be at least 1.55 0/00.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Loss of life,Serious injuries

SummaryOfEvents:
The Antigua and Barbuda registered general cargo vessel ORADE collided with the Apex Light tower at the confluence of the rivers Ouse and Trent while outbound from Howdendyke on the River Ouse.  ORADE subsequently grounded on the stone training walls of the rivers Ouse and Trent.
Initial attempts to refloat the vessel failed, due to the falling tide, and the vessel remained aground across the Ouse and Trent training walls with her bow protuding into a deeper water pocket adjacent to the River Trent training wall.  She was refloated at 0955 the following day with the assistance of two tugs.
Death and injury affecting crew members during testing of lifeboats

On February 24th 2005 at approximately 14.50 hours LT, the Liberian Flag crude oil tanker UIOMARAL was involved in a minor oil spill incident, whilst discharging her cargo in Kiire, Japn. during the vessel's discharge, the crew observed an oil sheen near the starboard quarter of the vessel. The discharge operation was immediately suspended , the Shipboard Oil Pollution emergency Plan was implemented, and the local authorities were notified. Upon further examination, less than 500 litres of oil were found to have been discharged into the sea. By 16.00 hours the crew had repaired the oil leak, which was found in the fuel oil tank, and the vessel was fit to proceed without further pollution. In view of the unpredictable nature of this incident the immediate follow-up action to identify and mitigate the pollution, and the relatively little harm caused to the environment, the port authorities did not impose any penalty. Flag state investigation wa conducted by obtaining the flag state report and follow-up communications for clarification after review, as necessary.
At 20.50 hours LT on 23rd February 2005 the general cargo vessel ARKLOW SAND ran aground due to a failure in the autopilot.

AT 17:10 ON 22 FEBRUARY 2005, M/V ITA WAS ON ROUTE FROM MINORCA TO ALFTHINA (GREECE) WHEN IT RAN AGROUND ON A REEF NEAR THE ISLAND OF USTICA, IN THE MARINE PROTECTED AREA. THERE WAS NO APPROPRIATE NAUTICAL CHART OF THIS AREA ON BOARD AND, IN ADDITION, THE SHIP HAD LEFT THE BAY OF MINORCA WITH A LEAK IN THE HULL, WHICH IT WAS KEEPING UNDER CONTROL WITH BILGE PUMPS.
