Location: NEW MANGALORE MRPL OIL TERMINAL, INDIA
SummaryOfEvents:
The MT Tassels arrived at New Mangalore port anchorage, India on 19 February 2005.  
The vessel was berthed at No. 11 Petroleum berth by 1730 on 20 February and commenced discharging its cargo of Iranian Mix crude by 1936 on 20 February 2005.

Discharging operations were progressing smoothly.  Completion of discharge operations was estimated by the crew at between 2100 and 2200 of 21 February.  However, between 1600 and 2000 some problems were encountered with Cargo Oil Pump no. 3.  The discharge rate was effectively reduced and the vessel was then estimated to complete its discharge operations by around midnight on 21 February.  During the final stages of discharge operations, however, it was found that the discharging rate had dropped even further and the completion would be delayed.  

At 0400 hrs on 22 February discharging operations were stopped for internal stripping as difficulty was encountered in pumping out the balance cargo in No. 2 cargo tank. The tank domes of No. 2C, 3C and 4C tanks were opened to ascertain the cause of the problem.  On opening No. 4C cargo tank the sound of air being sucked/drawn in could be heard.  Hence it was decided to enter 4C cargo tank to locate and resolve the suction problem.

The IG system was then stopped and fresh air blown inside the tank.  At about 0450 hrs on 22 February two crew members donned SCBA sets and entered the tank. At about 0509 they returned to the main deck and reported that they had checked the valve and had found no leaks there. At about 0538 they re-entered the tank to check the source of the pipeline & dresser coupling for the sound of the leaking air.

Location: Off the port of Newcastle, New South Wales
SummaryOfEvents:
At about 0440 local time on Saturday, 19 February 2005, a collision occurred between the bulk carrier GOA and the sailing vessel MARIE CHOCOLAT.  At the time of the collision GOA was in ballast, on a westerly heading, on the last leg of its voyage, to the anchorages offshore from the port of Newcastle, New South Wales.  The ship was to anchor on arrival in order to wait its turn to load a cargo of wheat for export to Italy.  MARIE CHOCOLAT, a privately owned yacht, was on a recreational voyage, heading south west, from Laurieton, NSW to Pittwater, north of Sydney.
MARIE CHOCOLAT sustained damage to its hull, mast, rigging and deck in the collision.  The yacht's Skipper initiated a distress call using an EPIRB and a mobile (cellular) telephone.  He then took the yacht to Newcastle under power for assessment and possible repair.
GOA sustained only slight scratching to the paintwork on the ship's side and continued to its designated anchorage.

During heating of water for use in a tank cleaning process a boiler explosion happened. The boiler front gate was blown out and blazes from the boiler started a fire in the boiler room. The fire was extinguised by fire-fighting service from ashore within an hour. No injuries. Damages to cables and other in the engine room. The vessel was towed to shipyard for repair.

On 15th February 2005 at 02.50 hours LT the vessel was approaching the route at Hals Barre, but went too far South because of the current. The officer on watch altered the course, but the ship hit the foundation of a fixed light, before it was back in the route.

Voyager was engaged on a Mediterranean cruise and on passage from Tunis to Barcelona. On 14 February 2005 the weather deteriorated and speed was reduced until the ship was in effect hove to making about 3 knots against the wind and seas. Voyager was struck by two waves in succession, breaking over the bow and advancing towards the bridge. A window at the centreline of the ship was forced inwards and a large quantity of water entered the bridge. The main engines stopped and the ship drifted beam on to the wind and seas, rolling heavily.

Difficulties were experienced in re-starting the main engines and operating them on local control from the engine room. With two engines running, the ship was turned away from the weather and sailed to Cagliari, accompanied initially by the LNG Carrier Gimi which provided communication and navigational assistance.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents: When the crew boarded the tug, which moored to a buoy, they found the engine room flooded and before pumps arrived the vessel sank. During the previous night in strong winds the tug had struck a sharp metal object protruding from the soft mud and punched an 8cm hole in the hull beneath the engine room. The area of the mooring is to be dredged for other possible objects. The vessel was raised nearly two weeks later and sent to a repair yard for repair.

The vessel which was carrying a cargo of steel pipes and containers sank after developing a list in heavy weather and at night.  
Eight crew members abandoned ship and were recovered by a container ship which responded to the distress alert and two who went missing lost their lives.
Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Loss of life

SummaryOfEvents: While sailing eastward, en route to Onahama Port, Fukushima Prefecture, the cargo ship Helena II, a Cambodian flag vessel (2,736 gross tons), went aground on the west coast of Kodomari Misaki, at a position 228º, 700 meters from Kodomari North Lighthouse, at 0540 hours on February 11, 2005.  The vessel was unable to refloat and stayed aground.  Logs, as her cargo, went adrift and were washed ashore on the nearby coast, causing huge damage to the fishing industry.  The hulk, which was left there without being removed, was broken into pieces by natural effects, including those caused by typhoons, and submerged underwater.

During the morning of Saturday 5th February 2005 the cargo vessel JOKULFELL departed from Copenhagen bound for the port of Reydarfjordy in Iceland.  The visibility was good; the wind was from the west at force 3 to 4 and the sea state was slight.
Two days earlier on the 3rd February in the port of Leipaya in Latvia the vessel had loaded a cargo of steel reinforcing bars, construction material, and several containers.  
On the 7th February the vessel was to the east of the Faeroe Islands and experiencing strong southerly winds of force 7 to 8 with 4 to 5 metre seas.  She was rolling and pitching moderately and at times heavily in response to the sea conditions.
At approximately 2040 hours (ship's time) on the evening of the 7th February 2005 the vessel experienced a particularly large roll to starboard from which she did not fully recover. 
Minutes later at 2053 hours as the list increased an MF DSC distress alert was sent from the JOKULFELL.
The vessel continued to roll heavily about a rapidly increasing list until she reached an angle of about 90 degrees from where she eventually sank. 
The crew jumped into the sea in their immersion suits.
A Danish Naval vessel, the VAEDDEREN which was operating in the area launched their Lynx rescue helicopter and recovered 5 survivors from the JOKULFELL at about 2344.  
The bodies of 4 other crew members were recovered from the sea the next day but 2 crew members have not been located and are presumed to have gone with the ship.
Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Loss of life

SummaryOfEvents: Transmar was on a voyage from Lappohja, Finland to Nyborg; Denmark. According to the voyage plan, the ship should have altered course at buoy No. 7 in the southern part of the Great Belt - off Keldsnor lighthouse. She, however, continued on its course. The vessel grounded on the coast about 30 minutes later with full speed.

On arrival at Dieppe, the Captain realised that the ship was unable to slow down and simultanuously an alarm signal in the engine room indicated "starboard propeller voltage failure". The back up system also failed to respond and the starboard propeller remained jammed in the position full steam ahead.  All attempts to stop the ship failed and at 14h04 DIEPPE rammed into the fender of the second dolphin.  The impact caused a blackout and engines stopped.  Tug assistance was requested and at 15h27 the ship finally berthed.  A rapid assessment revealed some serious damage to the bulb and bow visor.

The MV Aurelia loaded 30,510 metric tonnes of zinc and copper concentrate in bulk in her cargo holds No.2 through No.7.  The cargo was loaded from Punta Patache, Arica and Antofagasta in Chile and Callao, Peru.  The vessel departed Callao, Peru on 22 December 2004.

During the early hours of Wednesday 02 February 2005, the vessel was approaching the western coast of Ogasawara Islands.  The northerly wind had increased to gale force.  Just before 0600, the navigational OOW saw a streak of flash lightning running on the main deck in way of amidships.  A strong shock was immediately felt throughout the ship and it was noticed that the MV Aurelia took a severe trim by the head.  A distress message was sent by INMARSAT C and COSPAS-SARSAT.  The general alarm was sounded followed by a public address to the crew.  At around 06.15 hours LT, the master ordered the crew to abandon the vessel.

The starboard lifeboat was first swung out and six crewmembers, including the master, jumped on board.  During lowering, the forward fall jammed and the boat was left suspended against the ship’s side.  Almost immediately, the lifeboat was hit by a high wave, causing the lifeboat to crash against the vessel’s hull and tossing the crew members into the water.  Several other crewmembers abandoned the ship on board the ship’s liferafts.

Several hours later, a Japanese Coast Guard aircraft spotted the drifting survivors.  At around 13.00 hours LT, all survivors were airlifted and transported to Japan via Iwojima Naval Base for a medical check-up.

When the SAR operation was called off on Saturday 05 February 2005, six crewmembers were still reported missing.

The Pomerania had a ship on her starboard side. Both ships were aware of one another. The Pomerania Officer of Watch (OOW) accepted a closest point of approach (CPA) of 0,3 M and he occupied himself with other matters, in spite of the fact that the lookout tried to call his attention several times to the approaching situation. On board the Rio Grande the OOW unsuccessfully tried to call the Pomerania and then tried to take an evasive action. None of these manoeuvres however was made until the last minute. The two vessels collided in such way that the Pomerania run into the port side of the Rio Grande

ON JANUARY 28TH,  2005 AT ABOUT 15:15 HRS, A FIRE OCCURRED IN THE ENGINE ROOM ON BOARD  M/N "MOBY LOVE", WHICH WAS AT BERTH IN PIOMBINO. INVESTIGATIONS REVEALED THAT THE FIRE  STARTED BECAUSE THERE WAS AN OVER FLOW OF DIESEL FROM THE GASOLINE HEATER, POSITIONED NEXT TO THE MAIN PROPULSION ENGINE.

During departure from St.Thomas on January 27, 2005, a crew member got trapped while 
attempting to pass through a watertight door in a crew cabin area. The door was in remote 
closing mode and closed on his back so that the crew member became compressed against the 
door frame and was unable to breathe. Several other crewmembers rushed to his rescue but 
were unable to operate the door handle, as the trapped crew member’s shoulder blocked the 
movement of the handle. Engineers soon arrived to assist and managed to free the crew 
member by breaking the power supply to the hydraulic pump and unscrewing a pipe joint to 
bleed off the pressure. The crew member was freed after 8 – 10 minutes. The medical team 
attempted resuscitation without success.

InitialEvent: Accidents with life-saving appliances + Man overboard
SummaryOfEvents:
At about 0400 on 27 January 2005, a crew member on board the French Antarctic support vessel L'ASTROLABE went missing prior to going on watch.  At the time, the vessel was in the Southern Ocean, 234 nautical miles south of the Tasmanian port of Hobart. After a search of the vessel and sea, the crew member was found in the ocean near the position of the vessel at the time he was last seen on board.  When found, he was deceased.
In the subsequent operation to recover the deceased crew member, the second engineer suffered a severe laceration to his right hand, almost severing the thumb, when it became caught between the lifeboat fall block and the hook assembly on the after end of the lifeboat.

While on passage across the Pacific from Vancouver to Hakodate, Explorer encountered severe weather over several days during which superficial damage to deck fittings occurred and difficulties were experienced in securing lifeboats, tenders and gangways. On 27 January 2005, while making a speed of 7 knots, the ship was struck by two large waves in succession. Water was slow to clear from the foredeck and the second wave struck the bridge front, breaking a while house window near the centreline of the ship. A large quantity of water entered the bridge and caused severe water and physical damage to the control console. The main engines stopped and the ship drifted beam on to the weather.

 After overcoming difficulties in starting the main engines on local engine room control, the ship regained steerage way and altered course to place the wind and seas astern. The ship then diverted to Hawaii where essential repairs were made

InitialEvent: OTHER - flooding and sinking (sea water ingress through outboard shipside valve)
SummaryOfEvents:
The fishing vessel PAULA arrived in the Norwegian port of Selje, Maloy on the evening of 23rd January 2005 to discharge her catch of 270 tonnes of mackerel.
Prior to commencing discharge of cargo routine maintenance was carried out on the vessel's sea water system on the morning of 24th January 2005.
During this maintenance operation seawater entered the engine room through the port seawater suction strainer.
Efforts to halt the ingress of water proved unsuccessful and the engine room and adjacent spaces flooded causing the vessel to partially sink alongside the quay.
All persons escaped safely to the quayside without injury.  There was minimal pollution caused.

At about 0408 on 23 january 2005, just south of the Grimsby Middle bank in the Humber estuary on the east coast of the UK, the outbound UK flag Amenity collided with the in-bound norwegian flagged Tor Dania. Both vessels suffered extensive damage, but were able to berth without assistance before being withdrawn from service for repairs.There were no injuries or pollution.

The vessel touched the Moellegrund in Kerteminde Bay and got an approximately 40 meters long fracture in the bottom, and fuel tanks #3 ans #4 were opened to the sea with the result of the spillage of approximately 5 m3 light fuel oil on its way north in the Great Belt.

ALGA was on a voyage from Odense to Copenhagen loaded with 1016 MT steel scrap. After the passage of Fyns Hoved it was the intention to continue on a northerly course west of Bolsaks. The crew member, alone on the bridge, could not see the bouy and he set the propeller in neutral. Immediatly after the vessel foundered at Bolsaks shoal at 1.3 meters dept of water. Following a lightering of the tanks the ship was deemed "a total loss".

Some 20 minutes after casting off from Saint-Guénolé a fire was discovered in the engine room.  Attempts to extinguish the fire were unsuccessful and the crew of five abandonned ship and were rescued.  ALCOR on fire drifted and ran onto nearby reefs.

Location: 1 nautical Mile North of Erris Head, Co Mayo.
SummaryOfEvents:
At approximately midnight on Thursday 17 February 2005, the skipper of the yacht “Rondo” and his son left Sligo bound for Dublin in their 9-meter “Gibsea” class yacht. 
In view of the North Westerly weather conditions it was decided at the time to go south about with the option of sheltering at various locations along the way.

The following day, 18 February 2005 at approximately 19:00 hours when in a position about one nautical mile north West of “Erris Head” Co. Mayo, the Skipper was washed overboard. A search and rescue mission got underway resulting in the safe rescue of his son, the second crew member. At approximately 21:30 hours that evening, the skipper remained missing.

At approximately 10:00 hours on the morning of 19 February 2005 the body of the skipper was recovered from the sea by search and rescue units and taken to Mayo General Hospital for autopsy.

While on passage from Grand Turk to Port Everglades, a fire developed in the diesel generator room resulting in a loss of main electrical power and shut down of the main engines.  Emergency power was supplied by the emergency generator which started automatically and the fire was rapidly extinguished by the crew.  Propulsion and electrical power was restored and the vessel resumed passage to port, where the fire was investigated.  There were no injuries to any persons.

On 16th January 2005 at 17.10 hours LT  the ship was heading North in the Suez Canal, when it was found that the internal the stern tube bearing was damaged. The ship anchored and was later taken in tow to be repaired.

On 14th January 2005 the M/V ISOLA AZZURRA, which had sailed from Lavera, in France, arrived at Sarroch terminal for discharging operations.  About 7000 litres of gasoil were discharged, and in the evening the vessel left Sarroch terminal for the port of Livorno. During navigation an explosion occurrred in the ventilators in the forcastle, which left two crew members dead. A casualty investigation team from the local PSC office carried out an initial inspection on board, and found that the explosion was due to human modification of the non-return valve in the cargo tank's ventilation line. Explosive gas coming from cargo tank no. 6 entered the ventilator room and caused the explosion when the electrical switch in the room was turned on by a crew member, who died instantly.  Another crew member died as a result of the explosion.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

Location: Approach channel to port of Newhaven, England
SummaryOfEvents:
At 1946 UTC on 11 January 2005, the Italian registered ro-ro passenger ferry SARDINIA VERA ran aground in the approach channel to the port of Newhaven on the south coast of England.  The position of the grounding was in the charted deep water channel about 20 metres to starboard of the centreline, a position where the Master should have been able to expect sufficient depth of water to navigate safely.  The vessel re-floated at 2131 UTC with the rising tide and proceeded to sea stern first, where safety checks were completed before re-entering harbour to berth safely at 2223 UTC.  There were no injuries or pollution, and the vessel did not sustain any damage.
The grounding on 11 January brought to 13 the number of reportable accidents involving the two Transmanche Ferries vessels in the port of Newhaven in less than 4 years.  Ten of the accidents and incidents were groundings or near groundings, and three were collisions and contacts, one involving the other ferry DIEPPE.  As a consequence, MAIB took the opportunity to probe more deeply the management of safety at Newhaven as it pertained to the Newhaven-Dieppe ferry operation.

On 9th January 2005 at 13.50 hours LT a collision occurred between the fishing vessel VOLHARDING HD 36 and the general cargo ship SANDETTIE in a traffic seperation scheme in the North Sea. The collision was due to insufficient look out by both ships.

On 8th January 2005 the M/V SCHIEBORG ran into bad weather and sustained  damage to vessel and cargo (containers, SECU's) on deck. Due to heavy water on deck, the damaged deck cargo Calcium Carbide (IMO 4.3) caught fire at approximately 14.00 hours LT.  Attempts to extinguish the fire failed due to weather/ wind/ rolling vessel. In addition there was steering gear failure. The vessel sent an SOS to Lyngby Radio. The vessel dropped anchor, but the helicopter that came to assist could not take people from board, due to the weather circumstances (around 19.00 hrs). The crew left the vessel by lifeboat, and were picked up by supply vessel's  fast rescue boat, by jumping one by one into the water (9 January 2005 at around 01.50 hours LT).
